🎯 ABATE ➺  ( uh BAYT ) [ আবেইট্, অ‍য্াবেট]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  কমাব া, ঝিমা , দূর্করা, ক্ষীণ্করা, োঝিল্করা, হ্রাস্পাত্তযা, মন্দীভূি্করা, উপশম্হত্তযা,  রম্হত্তযা, কমা , 
প্রশঝমি্করা, ছুট্োদ্দদত্তযা, কমা, প্রবকাপ্হ্রাস্করা, হ্রাস্করা্ো্হওযা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to subside; to reduce  
 ❑ George spilled a pot of hot coffee on his leg. It hurt quite a bit. Then, gradually, the agony abated.  
 ❑ Bad weather abates when good weather begins to return. A rainstorm that does not let up con tin ues 
unabated. 
 ❑ A tax abatement is a reduction in taxes. Businesses are some times given tax abatements in return 
for building factories in places where there is a particular need for jobs.  
Synonyms:- subside, die down/away/out, lessen, ease (off), let up, decrease, diminish, moderate, decline, 
fade, dwindle, recede, tail off, peter out, taper off, wane, ebb, weaken, come to an end, remit 
Antonyms:- accumulate, balloon, build, enlarge, escalate, expand, grow, increase, intensify, mount, 
mushroom, rise, soar, swell, wax 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (verb transitive), (verb intransitive) ১ (সাঝহঝিযক)্(োিাস, িড়, ে যা, েযথা, জ্বর্ইিযাঝদ)্কম্ো্কমাব া; প্রশঝমি্
হওযা ো্করা; প্রবকাপ্হ্রাস্করা্ো্পাওযা। 
 ❑ ২্(আই ্সম্বন্ধীয)্োঝিল্করা; দশষ/বলাপ্করা। 
 ❑ abatement[Uncountable noun] প্রশম ; হ্রাসপ্রাঝি।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ The company operates in a very competitive industry, with little sign of the competitive pressures abating . 
 ❑ Space constraint did not abate their zeal to get a glimpse of the amazing cultural divergence of the nation. 
 ❑ this action would not have been sufficient to abate the odour nuisance 
 ❑ During the mid section of the morning I was able to abate my longing for biscuits by eating a slice of homemade 
fruit cake (courtesy of Welsh Dad Tony). 
 ❑ When the storms abate , the uncertainties do not. 
 ❑ the storm suddenly abated 
 ❑ We were both broke and working pub shifts but nothing could abate my appetite for conceiving low budget film 
ideas. 
 ❑ Surgery on the right ear diminished but did not completely abate her symptoms, so she underwent surgery on 
the left ear. 
 ❑ This defendant was required to abate the nuisance by noise identified in the abatement notice. 
 ❑ this action would not have been sufficient to abate the odor nuisance

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝসিংহাস ্িযাগ্করা, অ‍স্বীকার্করা, প্রিযাখ্যা ্করা, িযাগ্করা, পঝরিযাগ্করা, আ ুষ্ঠাঝ কভাবে্ো্অ‍ ুপঝিি্
থাঝকযা্পঝরিযাগ্করা্(কমম, পদ, ঝসিংহাস )   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to step down from a position of power or responsibility  
 ❑ When King Edward VIII of England decided he would rather be mar ried to Wallis Warfield Simpson, 
an American divorcée, than be king of England, he turned in his crown and abdicated.  
 ❑ Even people who aren’t monarchs can abdicate their duties and re spon si bil i ties. 
 ❑ Abby abdicated her responsibilities as a secretary by dump ing in the garbage the reports she was 
supposed to type and flying to the Ba ha mas.

Antonyms:- accepttake up

🎯 ABERRATION ➺  ( ab uh RAY shun ) [ অ‍যাোবরইশন্]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝেপথগাঝমিা, সামঝযক্সৃ্মঝিভ্রিংশ, স্খল , ঝেকার, ঝেপথগম ,  ীঝিভ্রিংশ, মঝিভ্রিংশ, সামঝযক্সৃ্মঝিভ্রিংশ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ n something not typical; a de vi a tion from the stan dard  
 ❑ SØren’s bad behavior was an aberration. So was Harry’s good be hav ior. That is, SØren’s was usually 
good and Harry’s was usu al ly bad. 
 ❑ The chef at this restaurant is dread ful; the good meal we just had was an aberration.  
 ❑ A snowstorm in June is an aberration; snow doesn’t nor mal ly fall in June. 
 ❑ An aberration is an aberrant (uh BER unt) occurrence. 
 ❑ SØren’s be hav ior was ab er rant. The summer snowstorm was ab er rant.  
 ❑ Note carefully the pronunciation of these words.  
Synonyms:- anomaly, deviation, departure from the norm, divergence, abnormality, irregularity, variation, 
digression, freak, rogue, rarity, oddity, peculiarity, curiosity, quirk, mistake 
Antonyms:- mind, sanity, normality 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

অ‍স্বাভাঝেক।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ These tests score either chromosomal structural aberrations at metaphase or micronuclei at interphase.

🎯 ABHOR ➺  ( ab HOR ) [ আবব্হা(র)্, অ‍য্বহ্র]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  গভীর্ঘৃণার্দচ্াবখ্্দদখ্া, ঘৃণাসহকাবর্পঝরহার্করা   
Word Smart Meaning:v to hate very, very much; to detest • Emanuel ab horred having anvils dropped on 
his head. 
 ❑ To abhor something is to view it with horror. Hating a person is almost friendly in comparison with 
abhorring him or her. 
 ❑ To abhor raw chicken livers is to have an ab hor rence of them or to find them abhorrent.  
Synonyms:- detest, hate, loathe, despise, execrate, regard with disgust, shrink from, recoil from, shudder 
at, abominate 
Antonyms:- love, adore 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (verb transitive) (abhorred, abhorring, abhors) ঘৃণা্ো্অ‍েজ্ঞা্করা; ঘৃণাভবর্পঝরহার্করা। 
 ❑ abhorrence [আবহ্রানস্্ America(n) আেবহারন্স্্]্্[Uncountable noun] ঘৃণা; ঝেিৃষ্ণা; জুগুিা:্regard something 
with abhorrence; an object of abhorrence. 
 ❑ abhorrent [আবহ্রানট্্্America(n) আবব্হারন্ট্্]্্(adjective) ঘৃণয; জঘ য; ঝেিৃষ্ণাজ ক।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ The president abhors dissent and is totally dismissive not only of dissenters, but also of the people's right to 
dissent. 
 ❑ I make this prediction based on what we know about biology, which is that natures abhors uniformity. 
 ❑ Healthcare professionals abhor politicians' interference in the NHS. 
 ❑ professional tax preparers abhor a flat tax because it would dry up their business 
 ❑ He abhors anything that adds to the cost of doing business, and politicians who show insufficient urgency about 
tackling the wider threats to business. 
 ❑ This is how they behave, these ‘liberationists’ and ‘democrats’, these foes of conspiracy, these abhorrers of 
secrecy! 
 ❑ I'm one of those people who is always on time, and abhors lateness. 
 ❑ Your enemies and abhorrers look on with mild amusement.

 ❑ Perhaps 90 percent of the time, when you en coun ter this word it will be followed by the word poverty.

🎯 ABORTIVE ➺  ( uh BOR tiv ) [ আবোঝটভ্, অ‍য্ােরঝটভ্]্

Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj unsuccessful  
 ❑ Marie and Elizabeth made an abortive effort to bake a birthday cake; that is, their effort did not result 
in a birthday cake. 
 ❑ Fred’s attempt to climb the mountain was abortive; he fell off when he was halfway up. 
 ❑ To abort something is to end it before it is completed. An aborted preg nan cy, called an abortion, is 
one that ends before the baby is born. An abortion in this sense doesn’t have to be the result of a 
controversial medical procedure.  
Synonyms:- unsuccessful, failed, vain, thwarted, futile, useless, worthless, ineffective, ineffectual, to no 
effect, inefficacious, fruitless, unproductive, unavailing, to no avail, sterile, nugatory, bootless 
Antonyms:- deadly, effective, effectual, efficacious, efficient, potent, productive, profitable, virtuous, 
successful

🎯 ABRIDGE ➺  ( uh BRIJ ) [ আঝিজ্, অ‍য্াঝিজ]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  সিংঝক্ষি্করা, সিংবক্ষপ্করা, কমাব া, সারসিংবক্ষপ্করা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to shorten; to condense  
 ❑ The thoughtful editor abridged the massive book by remov ing the boring parts. 
 ❑ An abridged dictionary is one that has been shortened to keep it from crushing desks and people’s 
laps. 
 ❑ An abridgment is a shortened or condensed work.  
Synonyms:- shorten, cut, cut short, cut down, curtail, truncate, trim, crop, clip, pare down, prune, 
abbreviate, condense, contract, compress, reduce, decrease, shrink, summarize, sum up, abstract, précis, 
synopsize, give a digest of, put in a nutshell, edit, epitomize 
Antonyms:- elongate, extend, prolong, protract, expand

 🗹  (verb transitive) (ঝেবশষ্কবর্দকাব া্পুস্তবকর শব্দসিংখ্যা্কঝমবয)্সিংঝক্ষি্করা:্to abridge a book like a novel, 
play etc; an abridged version of War and Peace. 
 ❑ abridgement, abridgment, [Uncountable noun(s)] সিংবক্ষপকরণ; [Countable noun(s)] সিংবক্ষঝপি্েস্তু, ঝেবশষি 
গ্র্ন্থ।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ I have the right to free speech, for example, and you can ask me to apologize for anything I say that offends you, 
and that request would have no bearing on whether my freedom of speech was being abridged . 
 ❑ The evidence clearly shows that the city's police powers are not abridged in any manner and that the agreement 
is expressly subject to the remedies available to the city under the Omaha Municipal Code. 
 ❑ No state could abridge those privileges or immunities, or deny any person due process or the equal protection of 
the law. 
 ❑ He has the full-length book, various abridged versions of the book, the video, the CD, the CD-ROM and the 
DVD. 
 ❑ The evidence clearly shows that the city's police powers are not abridged in any manner and that the agreement 
is expressly subject to the remedies available to the city under the Omaha Municipal Code.

 ❑ The cassettes have been abridged from the original stories 

 

🎯 ABSOLUTE ➺  ( AB suh loot ) [ অ‍যাবস্ালূট, অ‍য্ােসলুট]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍কাটয, পরম, চ্রম, পূণ,ম  অ‍োি, অ‍ঝিিীয, শিমহী , দেষ্ঠ, অ‍ঝমে, দভজালহী , ঝেশুদ্ধ, খ্াাঁঝট, অ‍সীম, ঝ ঝেমকল্প, 
পুরাদস্তুর, পূণস্বম ািী , সােমবভৌম, স্বযমূ্ভ, েযঝিক্রমী, ঝ পাি ীয, ঝ জমল, গুণািীি, পর, ঝ ঝিি, সমূ্পণম, অ‍ঝ যঝিি, দসচ্ছাচ্ারী,

📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 

Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj total; unlimited  
 ❑ An absolute ruler is one who is ruled by no one else. An absolute mess is a total mess. An absolute 
rule is one that has no exceptions and that you must follow, no two ways about it. 
 ❑ Absolute is also a noun. It means something that is total, un lim it ed, or perfect. Death, for living 
things, is an absolute. There just isn’t any way around it.  
Synonyms:- complete, total, utter, out-and-out, outright, entire, perfect, pure, decided, thorough, 
thoroughgoing, undivided, unqualified, unadulterated, unalloyed, unmodified, unreserved, downright, 
undiluted, consummate, unmitigated, sheer, arrant, rank, dyed-in-the-wool 
Antonyms:- limited, relative 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

 ❑ ৪্ঝ িঃশিম; শিমহী :্absolute authority. 
 ❑ ৫ অ‍  যসাবপক্ষ; চূ্ড়ান্ত; ঝ ঝেমকল্প; ঝ রঙু্কশ; পরম; চ্রম; ঝ ঝিি:্absolute death. 
 ❑ absolute zero িাঝিকভাবে্সম্ভে্সেমঝ ম্ন্িাপমাত্রা; চ্রম ঝহমাঙ্ক্➩্-২৭৩.১৫০C।্দ্রষ্টেয্পঝর.্৫। 
 ❑ absolutely ১্সমূ্পণমভাবে: absolutely impossible. 
 ❑ ২্ঝ িঃশিমভাবে। 
 ❑ ৩ [অ‍যাবস্ালূট্ঝ্ল]্(কথয, প্রবের্জোবে্ো্মন্তেয্ঝহসাবে)্অ‍েশয; ঝ িঃসবন্দবহ।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ The Prince of Monaco was an absolute ruler until a constitution was promulgated in 1911.

because of his bad health and its affect on his ability to question witnesses. 
 ❑ King and Queen were absolute monarchs, yet fallibly human.

nobody, and was only answerable to God for its exercise.

 ❑ If rights were absolute 
 ❑ there would be no question of weighing them against ‘interests’ to determine when the rights must yield. 
 ❑ Sometimes, absolute silence is the most satisfying sound. 
 ❑ The right will no doubt point out that this is a comparison of relative, rather than absolute poverty. 
 ❑ He would govern in the interests of the people as an enlightened but absolute ruler. 
 ❑ But many economists believe that relative poverty rather than absolute standards is what matters. 

 

🎯 ABSOLVE ➺  ( ab ZOLV ) [ আবজ্লভ্্,্ অ‍য্াবস্লভ্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  োিযোিকিা্দথবক্মুঝি, ঝেচ্াবর্ঝ বদমাষ্দঘাষণা্করা, মুঝিদা  করা, ক্ষমা্করা, পাপ্হইবি্মুি্করা , দদাষক্ষাল ্

🎯 ADAMANT ➺  ( AD uh munt ) [ অ‍যািামানট্্, অ‍য্ািামযান্ট]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  কবঠার, হীরা্ো্ঐ্জািীয্অ‍ঝি্কঝঠ ্েস্তু, অ‍ ড়, অ‍ ম ীয, হীরক, দগাাঁযার্দগাঝেন্দ, অ‍িযন্ত্কঝঠ ্েস্তু, দজদী, হীরা্
ো্ঐ্জািীয্অ‍ঝি্কঝঠ ্েস্তু, অ‍ ম ীয   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj stubborn; unyielding; com plete ly in flex i ble  
 ❑ • Candice was adamant: She would never go out with Paul again. 
 ❑ A very hard substance, like a diamond, is also adamant. Adamantine (ad uh MAN teen) and ad a 
mant are synonyms. Adamancy is being ad a mant.  
Synonyms:- unshakable, immovable, inflexible, unwavering, unswerving, uncompromising, insistent, 
resolute, resolved, determined, firm, steadfast, stubborn, unrelenting, diehard, unyielding, unbending, 
rigid, obdurate, inexorable, intransigent, (dead) set, diamond

Antonyms:- compliant

 🗹  [Countable noun] কাটা্ো্ভাঙ্গা্যায্ া্েবল্কঝথি পাথরঝেবশষ; হহঝরক। 
 ❑ □(predicatively adjective) অ‍ ম ীয; অ‍ঝেচ্লঝচ্ত্ত; দৃঢ়সিংকল্প; অ‍ ড়।

increases.

up residence.

🎯 ADROIT ➺  ( uh DROYT ) [ আেইট্, অ‍য্ােযট]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  পটু, দক্ষ, কুশলী, ঝ পুণ, িৎপর, দক্ষত্রজ্ঞ, িুরন্ধর, কমমদক্ষ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj skillful; dexterous; clever; shrewd; so cial ly at ease  
 ❑ Julio was an adroit salesperson: His highly skilled pitch, backed up by extensive product knowledge, 
nearly always resulted in a sale. 

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ Adroit comes from the French word for right (as in the direction), and refers to an old superstition 
that right-handedness is superior. It’s a synonym of dexterous (which comes from the Latin for right) 
and an antonym of gauche and maladroit.  
 ❑ My brilliant accountant adroitly whipped my taxes into shape, then made a gauche remark about my 
ignorance of financial matters.  
Synonyms:- skillful, adept, dexterous, deft, nimble, able, capable, skilled, expert, masterly, masterful, 
master, practiced, handy, polished, slick, proficient, accomplished, gifted, talented, quick-witted, quick-
thinking, clever, smart, sharp, cunning, wily, resourceful, astute, shrewd, canny, nifty, crack, mean, ace, 
A1, clueful, on the ball, savvy, crackerjack 
Antonyms:- amateur, artless, rude, unprofessional, maladroit 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  adroit (at/in) দক্ষ; ঝ পুণ; কুশলী; উদ্ভাে কুশল; কমমকুশল:্adroit handing of an awkward situation. 
 ❑ adroitlyদক্ষিার সবঙ্গ্ইিযাঝদ। 
 ❑ adroitnessদক্ষিা; ঝ পুণিা্ইিযাঝদ।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Again the Chilingirian chose a very fast tempo, which required the first violin especially to be extremely adroit . 
 ❑ So in the end they could only scrape through 1-0 with a goal by the ever inventive and adroit Dutchman, Dennis 
Bergkamp. 
 ❑ Although the attack was adroit - and enjoyable to read - its arguments are not convincing. 
 ❑ You mentioned in your presentation that particularly younger people who are both adroit and adept at the new 
technology, thrive in that environment. 
 ❑ With an adroit and intelligent adaptation, Ruiz has forced us to reflect on how we make our own lives into 
stories, and how we tell them to ourselves. 
 ❑ he was adroit at tax avoidance 
 ❑ It was a fine start to what promises to be an excellent season of historic rallying. 
 ❑ My favourite ever piece of digital art is an excellent example of this kind of sublime infinity. 
 ❑ the food was excellent 
 ❑ He looks very strong in defence and should prove an excellent asset and the first class centre. 
 ❑ There was a cool, shaded garden and an excellent veranda from which to watch the street go by.

🎯 ADVERSE ➺  ( ad VURS ) [ অ‍যাডভ্াস্া্ , অ‍য্ািভারস]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ক্ষঝিকর, ঝেবরািী, ঝেপ্রিীপ, ঝেমুখ্, অ‍সুঝেিাজ ক, প্রঝিকূল, ঝেপরীি, অ‍  ুকূল, ঝেরূদ্ধ, পঝরপন্থী, অ‍বশাভ , মন্দ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj unfavorable; antagonistic  
 ❑ We had to play our soccer match under adverse conditions: It was snow ing and only three members 
of our team had both ered to show up. 
 ❑ Airplanes often don’t fly in adverse weather. An airplane that took off in bad weather and reached its 
des ti na tion safely would be said to have overcome adversity. Adversity means mis for tune or 
unfavorable circum stanc es. To do something “in the face of ad ver si ty” is to undertake a task despite 
obstacles. Some people are at their best in adversity because they rise to the oc ca sion. 
 ❑ A word often confused with adverse is averse (uh VURS)➭ . The two are related but they don’t mean 
quite the same thing. A person who is averse to doing something is a person who doesn’t want to do it. To 
be averse to something is to be opposed to doing it—to have an aversion to doing it.  
Synonyms:- unfavorable, disadvantageous, inauspicious, unpropitious, unfortunate, unlucky, untimely, 
untoward 
Antonyms:- advantageous, favorable, friendly, positive, sympathetic, favourable 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  প্রঝিকূল; অ‍  ুকূল; ঝেরুদ্ধ; হেরী।

Examples:- 
 ❑ Despite the adverse blustery weather conditions, it was clear that Oxford had the edge. 
 ❑ The trials had been cancelled after the drug was found to cause an adverse reaction. 
 ❑ So when lawn edges become overgrown and tatty, it can have an adverse effect on the look of the whole garden. 
 ❑ She said the development would have major adverse impacts on the beauty of the landscape. 
 ❑ The development will not have any adverse effect upon bats or other wildlife living in the area. 
 ❑ adverse weather conditions 
 ❑ The trials had been cancelled after the drug was found to cause an adverse reaction. 
 ❑ It was bound to attract adverse publicity and bring the profession into disrepute. 
 ❑ Fortunately, most schools forced to close due to the adverse weather were due to reopen today. 
 ❑ A hike in interest rates could have an adverse effect on house prices and in terms of consumer wealth.

 ❑ The most common adverse effects reported related to skin irritation and skin burning.

🎯 ALLEGE ➺  ( uh LEJ ) [ আবলজ্, এবলজ্]্   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  দঘাষণা্করা, দৃঢ়িার্সবঙ্গ্দকাব া্ঝকছু্েলা, যুঝি্ো্অ‍জুহাি ঝহসাবে্খ্াড়া্করা, সপবক্ষ্যুঝি্দদখ্া , ঝেপবখ্্যুঝি্
দদখ্া ,  ঝজর্দদখ্া , অ‍ঝভবযাগ করা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to assert without proof  
 ❑ If I say, “Cedrick alleges that I stole his hat,” I am saying two things: 
 ❑ Cedrick says I stole his hat. 
 ❑ I say I didn’t do it. 
 ❑ To allege something is to assert it without proving it. Such an as ser tion is called an allegation (al 
uh GAY shun). 
 ❑ The adjective is alleged (uh LEJD). If the police accuse someone of having committed a crime, news pa 
pers will usually refer to that person as an alleged crim i nal. 
 ❑ The police have alleged that he or she com mit ted the crime, but a jury hasn’t made a decision yet.  
Synonyms:- claim, assert, charge, accuse, declare, state, contend, argue, affirm, maintain, attest, testify, 
swear, aver 
Antonyms:- deny, gainsay, deny 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (verb transitive) অ‍ঝভবযাগ্করা; সপবক্ষ্ো্ঝেপবক্ষ যুঝি্দদখ্াব া;  ঝজর্দদখ্াব া:্An alleged thief, দচ্ার্ঝহবসবে্
কঝথি েযঝি। 
 ❑ allegation [অ‍যালাবগইশন্]্[Uncountable noun] অ‍ঝভবযাগ; [Countable noun] (অ‍ঝভবযাবগর)্প্রমাণঝেহী ্ঝেেৃঝি:্

 ❑ Traffic on the laneway was also being impeded, he alleged .

🎯 ALLOY ➺  ( AL oy ) [ অ‍যালয, অ‍য্ালয়]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  খ্াদ্দমশা , আাঁিার্কবর্দিালা, সিংকর্িািু, ঝমে্িািু, মূলযো  িািুর্সাবথ্কমদামী্িািুর্ঝমেণ, খ্াদ, পাই , 
সঙ্কর্িািু, ঝ কৃষ্ট্েস্তর্ঝমেণ, মা , পা , সঙ্কর্ো্ঝমে্িািু   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ n a combination of two or more things, usually metals  
 ❑ Brass is an alloy of copper and zinc. That is, you make brass by com bin ing copper and zinc. 
 ❑ Alloy (uh LOY) is often used as a verb. To alloy two things is to mix them together. There is usually 
an implication that the mix ture is less than the sum of the parts. That is, there is often some thing un de 
sir able or debased about an alloy (as opposed to a pure sub stance). 
 ❑ Unalloyed means undiluted or pure. Unalloyed dislike is dis like un di min ished by any positive 
feelings; unalloyed love is love un di min ished by any negative feelings.  
Synonyms:- debase, mixture, mix, amalgam, fusion, meld, blend, compound, combination, composite, 
union, admixture 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

Examples:-

layers of metallic alloys , made up of cobalt, platinum, chromium and boron.

their structures. 
 ❑ The precious metals could be extracted by stirring the molten alloy with molten lead: gold and silver dissolved in 
the lead while copper did not. 
 ❑ The hydride is a complex alloy of rare-earth elements and other metals that may be decomposed and reformed 
reversibly. 
 ❑ This new material, an alloy of titanium and nickel, has an ability to return to its original shape after bending.

 ❑ flat pieces of alloy

 ❑ heating and melting the mixture, and allowing it to cool and solidify.

🎯 ALLUSION ➺  ( uh LOO zhun ) [ আলূজ্ন্,্ এলুজ্ন্]্   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  পবরাক্ষ্উবেখ্্ো্ইঝঙ্গি, ইশারা, ইঝঙ্গি, টীকা, ঝটপ্পঝ , উবেখ্, উদ্ঘাি, পবরাক্ষ্উবেখ্, পবরাক্ষভাবে্উবেঝখ্ি্ঝেষয, 
মন্তেয, পূেমসূত্র ো্প্রসঙ্গ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ n an indirect reference (often to a lit er ary work); a hint  
 ❑ To allude to something is to refer to it indirectly. 
 ❑ When Ralph said, “I sometimes wonder whether to be or not to be,” he was alluding to a famous line 
in Hamlet. If Ralph had said, “As Hamlet said, ‘To be or not to be, that is the ques tion,’” his statement 
would have been a direct reference, not an al lu sion. 
 ❑ An allusion is an allusion only if the source isn’t identified di rect ly. 
 ❑ Anything else is a reference or a quotation. 
 ❑ If Andrea says, “I enjoyed your birthday party,” she isn’t allud ing to the birthday party; she’s men tion 
ing it. But if she says, “I like the way you blow out candles,” she is alluding to the party.  
Synonyms:- reference to, mention of, suggestion of, hint to, intimation of, comment on, remark on 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  [Countable noun] allusion to পবরাক্ষ্উবেখ্:্Eliot’s Waste Land is difficult because it is full of allusions 
to past beliefs and ideas. 
 ❑ allusive [আলূঝসভ্]্(adjective) পবরাক্ষ্উবেখ্সিংেঝলি।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ I'm making the really clear case that I know the difference between evidence and what is allusion and assertion 
and the rest. 
 ❑ We need the connections formed by allusion ; we understand the new in light of the old, and so our language 
links us to older traditions. 
 ❑ a classical allusion 
 ❑ Citation and allusion have a long and continuing history as literary practices, yet they are difficult to distinguish 
from theft. 
 ❑ But any meaning could be expressed, so that the language brought into play whole new principles of allusion and 
definition. 
 ❑ To be damned by a professional wordsmith, sneered at by a master of metaphor and allusion 
 ❑ well, it was beyond endurance. 
 ❑ an allusion to Shakespeare 
 ❑ Such Biblical allusion was in stark contrast to the welter of less printable comments being bellowed by the 
faithful. 
 ❑ The stanza is written like the formulaic examples of wit and allusion in old-fashioned riddle books.

🎯 AMNESTY ➺  ( AM nuh stee ) [ অ‍যাম ্াঝস্ট, অ‍য্ামঝ্ স্ঝ্ট]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  রাজক্ষমা, সমস্ত্অ‍পরািীবক্ক্ষমা, আন্তজমাঝিক্ক্ষমা, েযাপক ক্ষমা, পঝররাজক্ষমা, রাজত ঝিক্েন্দীবদর্মুঝি, 
ঝেবশষি্রাষ্ট্রঝেবরািী্অ‍পরাবির দক্ষবত্র্প্রদঝশমি্সািারণ্ক্ষমা্।   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ n an official pardon for a group of people who have violated a law or policy  
 ❑ Amnesty comes from the same root as amnesia, the condition that causes characters in movies to 
forget everything except how to speak English and drive their cars. 
 ❑ An amnesty is an official forgetting. When a state government de clares a tax amnesty, it is saying 
that if people pay the taxes they owe, the gov ern ment will officially “forget” that they broke the law by 
not paying them in the first place. 
 ❑ The word amnesty always refers to a pardon given to a group or class of people. A pardon granted to a 
single person is simply a pardon.  
Synonyms:- pardon, pardoning, reprieve, grace, release, discharge 
Antonyms:- penalty, retribution 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  [Countable noun] ঝেবশষি্রাষ্ট্রঝেবরািী্অ‍পরাবির দক্ষবত্র্প্রদঝশমি্সািারণ্ক্ষমা।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Police are hoping people will take advantage of the amnesty to hand over weapons at stations before the 
penalties are made law. 
 ❑ So if a person takes advantage of the amnesty , other plaintiffs can still sue the person later, though the RIAA 
cannot. 
 ❑ Six confessed militants who surrendered to authorities under a government amnesty in July have since been 
released. 
 ❑ But this time the jails of the world will be less full - the coup leaders were granted an amnesty . 
 ❑ the new law granted amnesty to those who illegally left the country 
 ❑ an amnesty for political prisoners 
 ❑ ‘He will be given an amnesty 
 ❑ pardoned, after being judged guilty,’ he told the newspaper during a recent visit to Rome. 
 ❑ More than 1,000 weapons, including 450 guns, have been handed in during the amnesty 
 ❑ with more weapons still coming in to divisional police stations. 
 ❑ Refusing to grant political amnesty exacerbates the wounds of conflict.

📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS

prisoners serving sentences are granted an amnesty .

be arrested on sight, and would therefore not be attending.

🎯 ANACHRONISM ➺  ( uh NAK ruh niz um ) [ আ যাক্রাঝ জাম, অ‍য্া যাক্রঝ জ্ম্]্   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  একযুবগর্েস্তু, েযঝি, ঘট া্ইিযাঝদবক্ভুল্কবর্অ‍ য্যুবগর সিংবগ্জঝড়বয্দফলা, কালঝেপযময্ো্কালাঝিক্রমণ্
দদাষ, এবকোবর্দসবকল্েযঝি, েস্তু্ো্রীঝি ীঝি, কালতেষময, কালেযঝিক্রম, সমবযর্অ‍সঙ্গঝি্ো্ভুল, ঘট া ইিযাঝদবক্ভুল্কবর্
অ‍ য্যুবগর্সিংবগ্জঝড়বয্দফলা, কালঝেপযময্ো্কালাঝিক্রমণ্দদাষ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  n something out of place in time or history; an in con gru ity  
 ❑ In this day of impersonal hospitals, a family doctor who will visit you at home seems like an 
anachronism.  
 ❑ In these modern, liberated times, some women disdain the anach ro nis tic practice of a man’s 
holding open a door for a woman.  
Synonyms:- mistiming 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 ১্[Countable noun] কালঝ বদমবশ্ভুল; কাবলর্অ‍সঙ্গঝি; কালপ্রমাদ; কাবলর্ঝেচ্াবর্দেমা া ্দকাব া্ঝকছু:্Shakespeare’s 
Richard III is full of historical anachronism. 
 ❑ ২্দসবকবল্ঝহসাবে্ঝেবেঝচ্ি্েযঝি, প্রথা, দৃঝষ্টভঝঙ্গ্ইিযাঝদ।

 ❑ It's difficult to tell when this anachronism is deliberate, and when it is merely a lack of writerly control.

 ❑ the town is a throwback to medieval times, an anachronism that has survived the passing years 
 ❑ everything was as it would have appeared in centuries past apart from one anachronism, a bright yellow 
construction crane 
 ❑ In a world hurtling into a space-age, perhaps we need a bit of anachronism 
 ❑ a place that exudes such history. 
 ❑ it is anachronism to suppose that the official morality of the age was mere window dressing 
 ❑ Usually you will find me with my head in a book muttering at the unreality and anachronism in some flouncy, 
Austen thing. 
 ❑ Within the substitutional mode, anachronism was neither an aberration nor a mere rhetorical device, but a 
structural condition of artifacts. 

 

🎯 ANALOGY ➺  ( uh NAL uh jee ) [ আ যালাঝজ]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  সমিা, সাদৃশয, উপমা, িুল া, অ‍ ুরূপিা, উপঝমঝি, উপমা , আ ুরুপয, ঝমল, সমা িা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ n a comparison of one thing to another; sim i lar i ty  
 ❑ To say having an allergy feels like being bitten by an alligator would be to make or draw an analogy 
between an allergy and an alligator bite. 

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ Analogy usually refers to similarities between things that are not oth er wise very similar. If you don’t 
think an allergy is at all like an alligator bite, you might say, “That analogy doesn’t hold up.” To say that 
there is no analogy between an allergy and an alligator bite is to say that they are not anal o gous (uh 
NAL uh gus). 
 ❑ Something similar in a particular respect to something else is its analog (AN uh lawg), sometimes 
spelled analogue.  
Synonyms:- similarity, parallel, correspondence, likeness, resemblance, correlation, relation, kinship, 
equivalence, similitude, metaphor, simile 
Antonyms:- apophatismcataphatism 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

উপিাপ ্কবর্যুঝি্প্রদাব র্প্রঝক্রযার্সাহাবযয:্argue by analogy.  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Finally, I think that Wright, who has written a good deal about evolution, is missing a basic evolutionary 
analogy .

 ❑ In other words, the roller-coaster analogy is limited, and these limitations may weaken Pinedo's account. 
 ❑ But is preventive medicine really the proper analogy to contraception?

greeted with open arms. 
 ❑ he interprets logical functions by analogy with machines 
 ❑ There is also Plato's idea of the state as an analogy for the soul. 
 ❑ The proper analogy to many blogs is opinion magazines.

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ In grammar, the antecedent of a pronoun is the person, place, or thing to which it refers. In the 
previous sentence, the antecedent of it is antecedent. In the sentence “Bill and Harry were walking to 
geth er, and then he hit him,” it is impossible to determine what the an te ced ents of the pronouns (he 
and him) are. 
 ❑ Antecedent is related to a word that is similar in meaning: pre ce dent.  
Synonyms:- aetiology, ancestress, better half, blood relative, descendant, designatum, desynchronisation, 
desynchronization, factor, forefather, foremother, forerunner, full cousin, partner, patrilineal sib, patrisib, 
relative-in-law, sib, sire, synchronization, anterior, anticipatory, pre-existent, pre-existing, preceding, 
preexistent, preexisting, prevenient, prior 
Antonyms:- consequence, corollary, development, effect, fate, fruit, issue, outcome, outgrowth, product, 
result, sequel, sequence, upshot, subsequentdescendant 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  antecedent (to) (আ ুষ্ঠাঝ ক)্পূেমেিমী; পূেমগামী।

 ❑ ২ (plural) পূেমপুরুষগণ; দকাব া্েযঝি্ো্েযঝিবদর্অ‍িীি্ইঝিহাস।

Examples:- 
 ❑ Our psychology must therefore take account not only of the conditions antecedent to mental states, but of their 
resultant consequences as well. 
 ❑ If the antecedent of a conditional is false, the statement is always true!

acupuncture, may never have existed in traditional China in anything like the form that it is practised today.

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝেরাগ, ঝেিৃষ্ণা, অ‍ াসঝি, ঝেকষমণ, মজ্জাগি্ো্িাযী্ো মূলগি্অ‍ ীহা, ঝেবিষ, দিষ, ঝেবরাঝিিা, প্রঝিবযাগ,

 ❑ ২্[Uncountable noun] (এক েস্তুর্সবঙ্গ্অ‍ য্েস্তুর, পরস্পর্দুঝট্েস্তুর)্হেপরীিয; [Countable noun] এরূপ

antithetic [অ‍যানঝ্টথাঝটক], antithetical [অ‍যানঝ্টথাঝটকল্]্(adjective(s)) antithetically [অ‍যানঝ্টথাঝটঝি]  
Examples:-

 ❑ the antithesis between occult and rational mentalities 
 ❑ Okay, there's the thesis and antithesis , where's the synthesis?

🎯 APARTHEID ➺  ( uh PAHRT hyte ) [ আপা:ট্ব্হইট্]্

Word Smart Meaning:➭ n the former policy of ra cial seg re ga tion and op pres sion in the Republic of 
South Africa  
 ❑ The word apartheid is related to the word apart. Under apart heid in South Africa, blacks were kept 
apart from whites and denied all rights. 
 ❑ The word apartheid is sometimes applied to less radical forms of racial injustice and to other kinds of 
separation. Critics have sometimes accused American public schools of practicing ed u ca tion al apart 
heid by pro vid ing sub stan dard school ing for nonwhites.  
Synonyms:- glasnost, nativism, social action

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  আ ুষ্ঠাঝ ক্ো্যথাঝেঝি্অ‍ ুবমাদ ্ো্সমথম ্ো্মঞু্জঝর, সম্মঝি, অ‍ ুবমাদ

🎯 APPROPRIATE ➺  ( uh PROH pree ayt ) [ আবপ্রাঝপ্রআট্, আবপ্রাঝপ্রএইট্, অ‍য্াবপ্রাঝপ্রবযইট্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍ঝিকার্করা, ঝ বজর্করা, উপযুি, উপবযাগী, জুিসই, সুসিংগি, মা া সই, যথাযথ, অ‍ঝিকারভুি, অ‍ন্বথম, 
হেঝশষ্টযসূচ্ক, ঝঠকঝঠক, যবথাঝচ্ি, লাগসই, ক্ষম   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to take without per mis sion; to set aside for a par tic u lar use  
 ❑ Nick appropriated my lunch; he grabbed it out of my hands and ate it. So I appropriated Ed’s. 
 ❑ The deer and raccoons appropriated the vegetables in our garden last summer. This year we’ll build a 
better fence. 
 ❑ Don’t confuse the pronunciation of the verb to appropriate with the pro nun ci a tion of the adjective 
appropriate (uh PROH pree it)➭ . When Con gress decides to buy some new submarines, it ap pro pri 
ates mon ey for them. That is, it sets some money aside. The money thus set aside is called an 
appropriation. 
 ❑ When an elected official takes money that was supposed to be spent on submarines and spends it on a 
Rolls-Royce and a few mink coats, he is said to have mis ap pro pri at ed the money. 
 ❑ When the government decides to build a highway through your back yard, it expropriates your 
property for this purpose. That is, it uses its official authority to take possession of your property.  
Synonyms:- seize, commandeer, expropriate, annex, arrogate, sequestrate, sequester, take over, hijack, 
suitable, proper, fitting, apt, right, relevant, pertinent, apposite, convenient, opportune, seemly, befitting, 
ad rem, meet 
Antonyms:- inappropriate 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:- <strong>meaning_1:</strong> appropriate (for/to something) যথাযথ; 
যবথাঝচ্ি; মা া সই:্His style of writing is not appropriate to his subject. 
  Meaning_2: ☞ (verb transitive) ১্ঝেবশষ্উবেবশয্আলাদা্কবর্রাখ্া:্Tk 5,000.00 has been appropriated for 
building a community centre.

 ❑ The reunion is imperilled by the physical arduousness of the journey, the boys' suspicions about the father's 
true motives and the volatile dynamics among the three. 
 ❑ Technology has rendered once arduous tasks easy and opened up a world of possibilities for ordinary people. 
 ❑ Thanks to everyone who gave their time and effort to the arduous task. 
 ❑ This two and a half day nonstop boat trip is just part of the arduous journey to bring help. 
 ❑ Sometimes they have to walk great distances and then carry the water back - an arduous task. 
 ❑ an arduous journey 
 ❑ Artists say that getting their art shown in galleries is an arduous and difficult process. 
 ❑ It had been a long and arduous journey from her home in Scotland and she was weary to her bones. 
 ❑ It can be a long and arduous task and very often ends in failure. 
 ❑ Michael's task is an arduous one, but critical to the well-being of 2.5m people. 
 ❑ This is a long and arduous task, one that the authorities admit has had only very limited success to date.

Antonyms:- bleak, dark, depressing, desperate, dismal, dreary, gloomy, hopeless, inauspicious, pessimistic, 
unlikely 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

 ❑ auspiciouslyশুভক্ষবণ।

farming to warfare.

🎯 AUSTERE ➺  ( aw STEER ) [ ওস্ঝ্টআ(র), অ‍ঝষ্টযার]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍লিংকারহী , কবঠারভাোপন্ন, ঝ রাভরণ, সরল, ঝ রলিংকার, কঝঠ , উগ্র্, কৃচ্ছ্র, অ‍িুযগ্র্, একান্ত্অ‍ াড়ম্বর, কবঠার, 
কবঠার্আত্মসিংযমী, কবঠার, কবঠার আত্মসিংযমী   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj unadorned; stern; forbidding; with out excess  
 ❑ The Smiths’ house was austere; there was no furniture in it, and there was nothing hanging on the 
walls. 
 ❑ Quentin, with his austere personality, didn’t make many friends. Most people were too intimidated by 
him to introduce themselves and say hello. 
 ❑ The noun austerity (aw STER uh tee) is generally used to mean roughly the same thing as poverty. To 
live in austerity is to live without com forts. 
 ❑ Conditions in Austria were very austere after the war.  
Synonyms:- severe, stern, strict, harsh, steely, flinty, dour, grim, cold, frosty, unemotional, unfriendly, 
formal, stiff, reserved, aloof, forbidding, grave, solemn, serious, unsmiling, unsympathetic, unforgiving, 
hard, unyielding, unbending, inflexible, hard-boiled 
Antonyms:- clement, forbearing, gentle, lax, lenient, easy-goingfussy

 ❑ ২্(জীে যাত্রা, িা ্ও্রীঝি্সম্ববন্ধ)্অ‍ াড়ম্বর; ঝ রাভরণ; কবঠার; ঝেশুষ্ক।

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  দমৌ ভাবে্সম্মি্হওযা, ঝে া্আপঝত্তবি্দমব ্দ ওযা,  ীরবে্মাঝ যা লত্তযা, সম্মি্হত্তযা, অ‍ ুেিমী্হত্তযা,

Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to comply passively; to accept; to as sent; to agree  
 ❑ The pirates asked Pete to walk the plank; he took one look at their swords and then acquiesced.  
 ❑ To acquiesce is to do something without objection—to do it qui et ly. As the similarity of their 
spellings indicates, the words ac qui esce and quiet are closely related. They are both based on Latin 
words mean ing rest or be quiet. 
 ❑ Acquiesce is sometimes used sloppily as a simple syn onym for agree in situations in which it isn’t 
really appropriate. For example, it isn’t really possible to acquiesce noisily, en thu si as ti cal ly, or eager 
ly. Don’t forget the quiet in the middle. To ac qui esce is to exhibit acquiescence.  
Synonyms:- accept, consent to, agree to, allow, concede, assent to, concur with, give the nod to, comply 
with, cooperate with, give in to, bow to, yield to, submit to, go along with 
Antonyms:- dissent 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

 ❑ ২্acquiesce in দকাব া্েযেিা, ঝসদ্ধান্ত্ইিযাঝদ্ঝে া্প্রঝিোবদ্দমব ্দ ওযা:্to acquiesce in an absurd proposal.

Examples:-

society.

authentic.  
Synonyms:- apocryphal, questionable 
Antonyms:- TRUE

🎯 ARISTOCRATIC ➺  ( uh ris tuh KRAT ik ) [ অ‍য্াঝরষ্টক্রাঝটক]

 ❑ Prince Charles is aristocratic. He is a member of the British ar is toc ra cy. 
 ❑ Polo, which Prince Charles enjoys, is often said to be an aris to crat ic sport because it is typically 
played by priv i leged people. 
 ❑ It is possible to be an aristocrat (uh RIS tuh krat) without being rich, al though aris to crats tend to 
be quite wealthy. There is nothing you can do to become an aristocrat, short of being born into a family 
of them. 
 ❑ People who act as though they think they are better than ev ery one else are often said to be 
aristocratic. A person with an “aris to crat ic bearing” is a person who keeps his or her nose in the air 
and looks down on everyone else.  
Synonyms:- noble, titled, upper-class, blue-blooded, high-born, well-born, elite, upper-crust, top-drawer 
Antonyms:- lower-classlowly 
Examples:-

 ❑ In 1940 she married S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike, the scion of an equally aristocratic Christian family in the low 
country. 
 ❑ Much of this had been granted in the form of hereditary manorial estates to aristocratic families or important 
monasteries. 
 ❑ This is a legacy from the days of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, when social position was determined by 
aristocratic or civil service hierarchy.

decorated and perfectly furnished houses in Scotland.

 ❑ The real opposite of the sublime is, of course, the intransigently banal and commonsensical. 

 

🎯 BANE ➺  ( bayn ) [ দেইন,্ দেন]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍ঝভশাপ, ধ্বিংবসর্কারণ, দুিঃখ্দুদমশা, সেম াশ, ঝেষ, মৃিুা্য, ধ্বিংস, সেম াশ্ো্সেম াবশর্কারণ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ n poison; torment; cause of harm  
 ❑ Bane means poison (wolfbane is a kind of poisonous plant), but the word is usually used figuratively. 
To say that someone is the bane of your existence is to say that that person poisons your enjoyment of 
life. 
 ❑ Baneful means harmful.  
Synonyms:- scourge, plague, curse, blight, pest, nuisance, headache, nightmare, trial, hardship, cross to 
bear, burden, thorn in one's flesh/side, bitter pill, affliction, trouble, misery, woe, tribulation, misfortune, 
pain 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  [Uncountable noun] ১্(বকেল্সমাসেদ্ধ্পবদ)্ঝেষ: rat’s-bane. 
 ❑ ২্সেম াশ্ো্দুদমশার্দহিু:্Gambling was the bane of his life, জুযাবখ্লাই্িার্সেম াশ্কবরবছ। 
 ❑ baneful [দেইনফু্ল] (adjective) পাপ; অ‍শুভ:্a  baneful influence. 
 ❑ banefully [দেইনফু্ঝল]্(adverb) অ‍কলযাণকররূবপ।  
Examples:-

📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ When juvenile nuisance and disorder are the bane of so many neighbourhoods already, some people are not 
only fuelling this curse, but actually making a profit from it. 
 ❑ They had to be counted, bagged and labelled and they were the bane of my life. 
 ❑ This issue has absolutely been the bane of my life in this country for 32 years. 
 ❑ It's the bane of my life, and probably yours too. 
 ❑ the telephone was the bane of my life 
 ❑ the bane of the decorator is the long, narrow hall 
 ❑ That evil is malevolent violence, a curse that is the bane of our human existence. 
 ❑ All I am to him is the bane of his existence, the blight of his life, the central focus of why he hates his job and 
wants to kill himself. 
 ❑ the depressions that were the the bane of her existence 
 ❑ His dyslexia - the bane of his life - meant that he found writing difficult, and he preferred giving papers at 
meetings.

🎯 BELIE ➺  ( bih LYE ) [ ঝেলাই]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  আশা ুরূপ্ া্হওযা, ঝমথযা্িারণা্জন্মা , ঝমথযা্েণম া্প্রদা  করা, ঝমথযা্েঝলযা্প্রঝিপন্ন্করা, প্রমাণ্কঝরবি্অ‍মথম ্
হত্তযা, রক্ষা্কঝরবি অ‍সমথম্হত্তযা, ঝমথযা্ো্ভুল্ে ম া্দদওযা, আশা ুরূপ্ া্হওযা

 ❑ Melvin’s smile belied the grief he was feeling; despite his hap py ex pres sion he was terribly sad inside. 
 ❑ The messy appearance of the banquet table belied the huge effort that had gone into setting it up. 
 ❑ A word that is sometimes confused with belie is betray. To rework the first example above: Melvin 
was smil ing, but a small tear in one eye betrayed the grief he was feeling.  
Synonyms:- contradict, be at odds with, call into question, show/prove to be false, disprove, debunk,

Examples:- 
 ❑ Its clearly German exterior belies its delicate interior. 
 ❑ He may look like a rugged hillwalker, well-built and bearded - but his appearance belies the truth. 
 ❑ the notebooks belie Darwin's later recollection 
 ❑ the quality of the music seems to belie the criticism

 ❑ his lively, alert manner belied his years

 ❑ I was a first year medical student when I first realized that outward appearances occasionally belie the truth.

 ❑ To muse is to think about or ponder things. To be bemused, then, is to have been thinking about

 ❑ People often use the word bemused when they really mean amused, but bemusement is no laughing

🎯 BENEFACTOR ➺  ( BEN uh fak tur ) [ দেঝ ফযাকট্র]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  পৃষ্ঠবপাষক, ঝহিকারী, উপকারী্েযঝি, অ‍ ুগ্র্হকারী, দািা, উপকিমা, েনু্ধ, ঝেদযালয্ো্হাসপািাল্ইিযাঝদর্পৃষ্ঠবপাষক   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ n one who provides help, es pe cial ly in the form of a gift or donation  
 ❑ To give benefits is to be a benefactor. To receive benefits is to be a ben e fi cia ry. People very, very 
often confuse these two words. It would be to their benefit to keep them straight. 
 ❑ If your next-door neighbor rewrites his life insurance policy so that you will receive all his millions 
when he dies, then you be come the beneficiary of the policy. If your neighbor dies, he is your bene fac 
tor.  
 ❑ A malefactor (MAL uh fak tur) is a person who does bad things. 
 ❑ Batman and Robin made life hell for malefactors in Gotham 
 ❑ City. 
 ❑ Remember Maleficent, Sleeping Beauty’s evil nemesis? Her name is a variation of this idea.  
Synonyms:- patron, supporter, backer, sponsor, donor, contributor, subscriber, angel 
Antonyms:- beneficiary 
Examples:- 
 ❑ Most of the money for repairs came from community businesses and local benefactors . 
 ❑ The museum is supported by private benefactors as well as awards from national entities. 
 ❑ News that a mystery benefactor has chipped in money to provide City with more time to find a buyer will further 
boost morale. 
 ❑ Now the school is hoping that a sponsor or a benefactor will come forward to help to meet the costs so that 
Yorkshire can be represented in the final. 
 ❑ a low-interest loan from a benefactor allowed them to build a floor for the exhibition hall 
 ❑ Andy was very grateful to the mystery benefactor who provided his bail money even though he had no idea who 
the person was. 
 ❑ All of this has been made possible by the generous contributions of many benefactors at home and abroad.

🎯 BENEVOLENT ➺  ( beh NEV uh lunt ) [ ঝেব ভালান্টা্,্ দেঝ বভাবলন্ট]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝহতিষী, সদাশয, কলযাণময, েদা য, দা শীল, শুভাকাঙ্ক্ষী, উপঝচ্কীষুম, উপকিমা, পরাথমপর, পবরাপকাবরচু্ছ, 
পবরাপকাবরচু্ছ

act. To be benevolent is to bestow benefits. The United Way, like any charity, is a benevolent or ga ni za 
tion. 
 ❑ Malevolent (muh LEV uh lunt) means evil, or wishing to do harm.  
Synonyms:- kind, kindly, kindhearted, big-hearted, good-natured, good, benign, compassionate, caring, 
altruistic, humanitarian, philanthropic, generous, magnanimous, munificent, unselfish, openhanded, 
beneficent, bounteous

inhumane, insensate, sadistic, savage, truculent, unfeeling, unkind, vicious, wanton, malevolent

Examples:- 
 ❑ James has a winning grin, a benevolent smile and an infectious laugh. 
 ❑ Others were labelled infirm, defined as the deserving poor, and provided for by benevolent asylums or charities. 
 ❑ The charity gains financially, the company earns kudos, and the benevolent consumer gets to feel good about his 
or her contribution. 
 ❑ Property owned by a benevolent organization and used exclusively for benevolent purposes is exempt from 
taxation. 
 ❑ The benevolent fund needs donations so it can continue to combat isolation.

 ❑ Some paid for the privilege of nailing by contributing to a war charity or benevolent organization.

 ❑ He decided to adopt both these benevolent elements as his motif. 
 ❑ His benevolent smile was topped by the warm charm flowing from his eyes. 

 

🎯 BENIGN ➺  ( bih NYNE ) [ ঝে াইন,্ ঝে াই ]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍মাঝযক, কৃপালু, সদাশয, ফলপ্রদ, কৃপাময, শুভ, সদয, ক্ষমাকর, ক্ষমাপরাযণ, দক্ষমসিংকর, প্রসন্ন, স্বািযকর, অ‍ ুকূল, 
মৃদু, ঝেষম্ বহ্এম , ঝেপজ্জ ক্ য্এম , স্বািকর, প্রশন্ন, অ‍মাঝযক   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj gentle; not harmful; kind; mild  
 ❑ Karla has a benign personality; she is not at all unpleasant to be with. 
 ❑ The threat of revolution turned out to be benign; nothing much came of it. 
 ❑ Charlie was worried that he had cancer, but the lump on his leg turned out to be benign.  
 ❑ The difference between a benign person and a benevolent (see sepa rate entry) one is that the 
benevolent one is actively kind and gen er ous while the benign one is more passive. Benevolence is 
usually active generosity or kindness, while benignancy tends to mean sim ply not causing harm. 
 ❑ The opposite of a benign tumor is a malignant one. This is a tumor that can kill you. A malignant 
personality is one you wish a surgeon would remove. Malignant means nasty, evil, full of ill will. The 
word malignant also conveys a sense that evil is spread ing, as with a cancer. An adjective that means 
the same thing is malign.  

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ As a verb, malign has a different meaning. To malign someone is to say unfairly bad things about 
that person, to injure that person by telling evil lies about him or her. Slander and malign are synonyms.  
Synonyms:- kindly, kind, warmhearted, good-natured, friendly, warm, affectionate, agreeable, genial, 
congenial, cordial, approachable, tenderhearted, gentle, sympathetic, compassionate, caring, well-
disposed, benevolent 
Antonyms:- adverse, bad, baleful, dangerous, deleterious, evil, ill, injurious, mischievous, noxious, 
pernicious, wicked, malignmalignant 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  ১্(েযঝি)্সদয; সহৃদয;  ম্র; ভদ্র। 
 ❑ ২ (আেহাওযা্ইিযাঝদ)্শান্ত; অ‍ ুকূল। 
 ❑ ৩্(েযাঝি)্ঝেপজ্জ ক্ো িুাঁঝকপূণম্ য্এম :্a benign tumour. 
 ❑ দ্রষ্টেয্malignant (২). 
 ❑ benignly (adverb)  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Jersey's benign climate and free-draining sandy soil provide the ideal environment for over 80 species of 
lavender. 
 ❑ Fever may be a marker of sepsis, localized infection, occult bacteremia, or benign illness. 
 ❑ Jersey's benign climate and free-draining sandy soil provide the ideal environment for over 80 species of lavender.

🎯 BEQUEST ➺  ( bih KWEST ) [ ঝেবকযাবযস্ট্্,্ ঝেবকাবযস্টা্]্   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ভারাপমণ, অ‍ঝপমি্দাঝযত্ব, উইলিারা্প্রদা , েিংশিবরর্জ য রাঝখ্যা্যাত্তযা, ইচ্ছাপত্রিারা্দা , ইচ্ছা্পত্র্িারা্প্ররদত্ত্

Word Smart Meaning:➭ n something left to someone in a will  
 ❑ If your next-door neighbor leaves you all his millions in a will, the money is a bequest from him to 
you. It is not polite to request a bequest. Just keep smiling and hope for the best. 
 ❑ To leave something to someone in a will is to bequeath it. A bequest is something that has been 
bequeathed.  
Synonyms:- legacy, inheritance, endowment, settlement, estate, heritage, bestowal, devise, hereditament

🎯 BLASPHEMY ➺  ( BLAS fuh mee )   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  িমমঝ ন্দা, শ্বরঝ ন্দা, অ‍িাঝমমক্কথাোিমা, ঈশ্বর্ঝ ন্দা, পঝেত্র্ঝজঝ বসর্ঝ ন্দা, অ‍পঝেত্র্ভাষা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ n irreverence; an insult to some thing held sa cred; pro fan i ty  
 ❑ In the strictest sense, to commit blasphemy is to say nasty, insulting things about God. The word is 
used more broadly, though, to cover a wide range of nasty, insulting comments. 
 ❑ To blaspheme (blas FEEM) is to use swear words or say deeply irrev erent things. A person who says 
such things is blasphemous.  
Synonyms:- profanity, sacrilege, irreligion, irreverence, taking the Lord's name in vain, swearing, curse, 
cursing, impiety, desecration, execration 
Antonyms:- piety 
Examples:- 
 ❑ He told people he was the Son of God when he knew that, in saying so, people would either think him insane or 
accuse him of blasphemy . 
 ❑ Before I carefully elaborate on the his numerous and profane blasphemies , perhaps an introduction to the 
professor would be helpful. 
 ❑ That we can still think of wringing out a song from all this is worse than heresy, blasphemy , sacrilege. 
 ❑ Tracing the dry words with a finger, I wondered for a moment if a Goddess could commit blasphemy . 
 ❑ She said that the Goddess must get tired of hearing utter flattery or utter blasphemy . 
 ❑ he was detained on charges of blasphemy 
 ❑ Idols are worshipped by various religions, while idolatry is blasphemy to others. 
 ❑ Pity is the source of every mean, ignoble, cowardly vice; and the essential blasphemy against Truth. 
 ❑ A strict control of blasphemy and bad language and other offensive things was maintained. 
 ❑ In the name of free speech, the right to protest and artistic freedom, the offence of blasphemy should be 
abolished.

want to refer to the listing for fla grant.

those con cerns. 
 ❑ A hip young city dweller might reject life in the suburbs as being too bourgeois. A person whose

Antonyms:- length

🎯 CACOPHONY ➺  ( kuh KAHF uh nee ) [ কযাকফাঝ ]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  শ্রুঝিকটু্শব্দ, অ‍ঝমল, ককমশ্শব্দ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ n harsh-sounding mixture of words, voic es, or sounds  
 ❑ The parade’s two marching bands played simultaneously; the resulting cacophony drove many 
spectators to tears. 
 ❑ A cacophony isn’t just a lot of noise—it’s a lot of noise that doesn’t sound good together. A steam 
whistle blowing isn’t a cacophony. But a high school orchestra that had never rehearsed together might 
very well produce a ca coph o ny. The roar of en gines, horns, and sirens arising from a busy city street 
would be a cacophony. A lot of people all shouting at once would produce a cacophony.  
 ❑ Euphony is the opposite of ca coph o ny. Euphony is pleasing sound.  
Synonyms:- clangor, clank, clash, crepitation, disharmony, hubbub, katzenjammer, plonk, rattle, rattling, 
report, roaring, screaming, screech, shrilling, sizzle, slam, snap, spattering, uproar 
Antonyms:- quiet, silence, still, harmony 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 কাকুধ্বঝ ; দেসুর। 
 ❑ দ্রষ্টেয্discord (৩)। 
 ❑ cacophonous [কযাকফাঝ  াস্]্্(adjective) শ্রুঝিকটু; দেসুবরা।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ songs of unrelieved cacophony 
 ❑ The constant sound of Calcutta is the cacophony of horns and the descant of millions of crows. 
 ❑ The resultant cacophony afforded the proprietor his first opportunity to speak. 
 ❑ a cacophony of architectural styles 
 ❑ Outlined in the speech was a cacophony of putative legislation - it's going to be a packed parliamentary session. 
 ❑ This leaves the orchestra without a conductor, and a musical cacophony verging on dissonance. 
 ❑ Reality is a thunderous cacophony of millions of impressions surging in on us at every moment. 
 ❑ The result is a cacophony 
 ❑ and nobody is the wiser about what is happening or is likely to happen to the economy. 
 ❑ At the initial stage, there is bound to be a glut of representation resulting in a cacophony of rhetoric.

🎯 CANDOR ➺  ( KAN dur )

 ❑ To show candor is to be candid. What is candid about the cam era on “Candid Camera”? The camera

the office where they’re applying for a job. Candid does not mean concealed or hidden, even though the 
camera on “Can did Camera” is concealed. To be candid is to speak frankly.

                              http://

 ❑ I appreciated the student's candor in honestly evaluating these new techniques. 
 ❑ Why can't we get candor and directness in what is patently obvious to anyone?

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  পুাঁঝজোদ, ি িি, ি িিোদ, িঝ কিি, পুঝজোদ

tures. Your success or failure would depend on how many people decided to buy your pictures.

🎯 CAPITULATE ➺  ( kuh PICH uh layt ) [ কাঝপচু্বলইট্]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  আত্মসমপণম্করা, সিমািীব ্আত্মসমপমণ্করা, আত্মসমপমণ্করা, শিমািীব ্আত্মসমপমণ্করা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to surrender; to give up or give in  
 ❑ On the twentieth day of the strike, the workers capitulated and went back to work without a new

 ❑ So few students paid attention to Mr. Hernandez that he had to re ca pit u late his major points at 
the end of the class.

down one's arms, raise/show the white flag, throw in the towel

📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ Chronic is usually associated with something negative or un de sir able: chronic illness, chronic 
failure, chronic depression. You would be much less likely to encounter a reference to chronic suc cess or 
chronic hap pi ness, un less the writer or speaker was being ironic.  
 ❑ A chronic disease is one that lingers for a long time, doesn’t go away, or keeps coming back. The 
opposite of a chronic disease is an acute disease. An acute disease is one that comes and goes very 
quickly. It may be severe, but it doesn’t last forever.  
Synonyms:- continuing, degenerative, inveterate, long, usual 
Antonyms:- acute

responsibility. 

 

🎯 CHRONICLE ➺  ( KRAHN uh kul ) [ ক্রঝ কল্,্ ক্রঝ কল্]

Word Smart Meaning:➭ n a record of events in order of time; a his to ry  
 ❑ Sally’s diary provided her mother with a detailed chronicle of her daugh ter’s extracurricular 
activities. 
 ❑ Chronicle can also be used as a verb. 
 ❑ The reporter chronicled all the events of the revolution. 
 ❑ Chronology and chronicle are nearly synonyms: Both provide a chro no log i cal list of events. 
 ❑ Chronological means in order of time.

 🗹 [countable noun] কালা ুক্রঝমক্ঘট াপঝঞ্জ।

🎯 CIRCUITOUS ➺  ( sur KYOO uh tus ) [ সাঝকউইটাস্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  আাঁকাোাঁকা, দঘারাব া, েক্র, চ্ক্রাকার, ঘুর, ঘুরা, ঘুরা , দঘারা, দঘারা    
Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj roundabout; not fol low ing a di rect path  
 ❑ The circuitous bus route between the two cities went here, there, and everywhere, and it took an 
extremely long time to get any where. 
 ❑ The sales man’s route was circuitous—it wound aimlessly through many small towns. 
 ❑ A circuitous argument is one that rambles around for quite a while before making its point. 
 ❑ A circu i tous argument is very similar to a circular argument, which is one that ends up where it 
begins or attempts to prove something with out offer ing any new information. To say, “Straight means 
not curved, and curved means not straight,” is to give a circular, or tau to log i cal, def i ni tion of the word 
straight.  
Synonyms:- devious, indirect, roundabout 
Antonyms:- direct, straight, straightforward, direct 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (আ ুষ্ঠাঝ ক)্পবরাক্ষ; দঘারাব া; েৃত্তাকার:্a circuitous route.  
Examples:- 
 ❑ To reach the Sibneft wells, you have to travel a circuitous route. 
 ❑ To send equipment from one important supply depot to the other involved taking an impossibly circuitous route. 
 ❑ Adding an extra flight or flying a more circuitous route can boost mileage accumulations rapidly. 
 ❑ a circuitous line of reasoning 
 ❑ Having started out as a ‘proper’ actress, mine was a circuitous route to comedy. 
 ❑ One has to remember that pedestrians do not have the time or stamina for unnecessarily circuitous routes. 
 ❑ A walk through Bootham Park offers a circuitous route into York, keeping well away from the noise and fumes of 
Gillygate. 
 ❑ He took the most circuitous route through the building, hiding in the shadows and avoiding security cameras.

explode, inspissate, jelly, meld, melt, polymerize, resolve, syncretise, syncretize, thicken 
Antonyms:- part, section, separate, sever, split, sunder, split up 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (verb intransitive) ঝমঝলি্হওযা; একাঙ্গীভূি হওযা। 
 ❑ coalescence  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Pragmatists try to coalesce the quest for truth and the quest for justification by trotting out what Williams 
labels •the indistinguishability argument. 
 ❑ I shall try and coalesce my thoughts into something readable as soon as I can think of something. 
 ❑ Immediately popular, it helped to coalesce people around the movement. 
 ❑ the puddles had coalesced into shallow streams 
 ❑ I don't know how to coalesce my observations into a coherent picture. 
 ❑ the separate details coalesce to form a single body of scientific thought 
 ❑ The left needs to coalesce its resources around direct legal action against the right. 

 

🎯 COERCE ➺  ( koh URS ) [ দকাউআস্,্ দকাআরস]

 ❑ Shaft was cogent in explaining why he needed the confidential files, so we gave them to him. 
 ❑ The lawyer’s argument on his client’s behalf was not cogent, so the jury convicted his client. The jury

 ❑ Cogent reasons are extremely persuasive ones.

 ❑ Posturing is in fact all it is, in this case posturing for want of a cogent argument. 
 ❑ A stay will not be granted, unless there is cogent evidence that the appeal will be stifled.

🎯 COMPRISE ➺  ( kum PRYZE ) [ কামপ্্রাইজ্,্ কমপ্রাইজ]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍ন্তভূমি্করা্ো্রাখ্া, অ‍িংশীভূি্করা, গঝঠি্করা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to consist of  
 ❑ A football team comprises eleven players on offense and elev en play ers on defense. 
 ❑ A company comprises employees. 
 ❑ This word is often mis used. Be careful. Players do not “com prise” a foot ball team, and employees do 
not “comprise” a com pa ny. Nor can a football team be said to be “comprised of” players, or a company 
to be “comprised of” employees. These are com mon mis takes. Instead, you can say that players con sti 
tute or com pose a team, and that employees con sti tute or compose a com pa ny. 
 ❑ You can also say that a team consists of players or a company consists of employees.  
Synonyms:- answer, bear, contain, coruscate, enter, gravitate, head, kill, linger, loaf, lollygag, lubricate, 
make up, pay, prove, retard, run, throw, translate, twist 
Antonyms:- exclude 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (verb transitive) অ‍িংশ্সহবযাবগ্গঝঠি্হওযা; (অ‍িংশ্ো অ‍ঙ্গরূপ)্অ‍ন্তভুমি্করা:্The house comprises 3 
bedrooms, a kitchen and a living room. Women comprise a high proportion of our population.  
Examples:- 
 ❑ On race wheels, the core may incorporate spokes, and comprise a large portion of the wheel. 
 ❑ Direct purchases by state and local governments now comprise nearly 10 percent of GDP. 
 ❑ Aspiring competitive athletes comprise only a portion of Cunningham's business. 
 ❑ the country comprises twenty states

Word Smart Meaning:➭ n harmony; agreement  
 ❑ Nations that live in concord are nations that live together in peace. 
 ❑ The war between the neighboring tribes ended thirty years of con cord.  
 ❑ The faculty meeting was marked by concord; no one yelled at anyone else. 
 ❑ Discord is the opposite of concord. A faculty meeting where every one yelled at one another would be 
a faculty meeting marked by discord. It would be a dis cor dant meeting. 
 ❑ An accord is a formal agreement, usually reached after a dispute.

regularize, set, settle, square, support, underpin 
Antonyms:- conflict, discord, variance, disagree

🎯 CONGENITAL ➺  ( kun JEN uh tul ) [ কানব্জঝ ট্ল্,্ ক বজঝ টযাল]

📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 

Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj describing a trait or condition ac quired be tween con cep tion and birth;

 ❑ A congenital birth defect is one that is present at birth but was not caused by one’s genes. 
 ❑ The word is also used more loosely to describe any (usually bad) trait or behavior that is so firmly fixed 
it seems to be a part of a person’s nature. 
 ❑ A congenital liar is a natural liar, a person who can’t help but lie.  
Synonyms:- inborn, innate, nonheritable, noninheritable 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  জন্মগি্(েযাঝি্ইিযাঝদ); জন্ম্দথবক্অ‍থো্জবন্মর্আবগ দথবক্েিম া :্congenital blindness/idiocy. 
 ❑ He is a congenital liar.

defects.

 ❑ Aggregate also has to do with coming together. Can you think of additional words with the same

the stadium.

Word Smart Meaning:➭ n unanimity or general agree ment When there is a consensus, everybody feels 
the same way. 
 ❑ Contrary to how the word is often used, consensus implies more than just a rough agree ment or a 
majority opinion. Election results don’t reflect a con sen sus unless everyone or nearly ev ery one votes for 
the same can di date.  
Synonyms:- community, community of interests, concurrence, meeting of minds, sense of the meeting,

Antonyms:- conflict, disagreement

 🗹 ঝমল; ঐকয; ঐকমিয।

 ❑ Preston construed his contract as giving him the right to do any thing he wanted. 
 ❑ The law had always been construed as permitting the behavior for which Katya had been arrested. 
 ❑ The meaning of the poem, as I construed it, had to do with the love of a man for his dog. 
 ❑ To misconstrue is to misinterpret. 
 ❑ Tommy mis con strued Pamela’s smile, but he certainly did not mis con strue the slap she gave him.

 ❑ ৩্েযাকরণগি্েযাখ্যার উপবযাগী্হওযা:্This sentence won't construe.  
Examples:- 
 ❑ It is permissible, where the context so allows, to construe words used in the plural as including the singular. 
 ❑ All we need to do is to construe each action sentence as involving an implicit existential quantification, with the 
variable of quantification taking events as its possible values. 
 ❑ Although it is open to a court in limited circumstances to conclude that the words or syntax used is wrong, the 
purpose remains to construe the words used. 
 ❑ his words could hardly be construed as an apology 
 ❑ If I construe your remarks correctly, you disagree with the theory already advanced.

 ❑ A consummate pianist is an extremely good one. Nothing is lacking in the way he or she plays.

agreement. Note carefully the pronunciation of both parts of speech.

🎯 CONTENTIOUS ➺  ( kun TEN shus ) [ কানব্টনশ্াস্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  কলহঝ়প্র, োদা ুোদপূণম, কুস্বভাে, দমাকেমাঝ়প্র, ঝেিকম ূলক, কুাঁদুবল, কলহঝপ্রয, কলহপরাযণ, িগড়াবট

 ❑ A person looking for a fight is contentious.  
 ❑ Two people having a fight are contentious.  
 ❑ To be contentious in a dis cus sion is to make a lot of noisy ob jec tions.

may have to contend with the law.  
Synonyms:- argumentative, combative, controversial, disputatious, disputative, litigious 
Antonyms:- pacific, peaceable, peaceful

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS

or make a new case should rarely be allowed. 

 

🎯 CONTIGUOUS ➺  ( kun TIG yoo us ) [ কানঝ্টঝগউআস্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  সিংলগ্ন, পাশ্বমেিমী, ঝ কটি, অ‍েযেঝহি, পাশাপাঝশ, লাগাত্ত, প্রিযাসন্ন, সঝন্নঝহি, লাবগাযা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj side by side; adjoining  
 ❑ Two countries that share a border are contiguous; so are two events that happened one right after the 
other. 
 ❑ If two countries are contiguous, the territory they cover is contin u ous. That is, it spreads or 
continues across both countries without any interruption.  
Synonyms:- adjacent, close, connected, conterminous, immediate, neighboring 
Antonyms:- distant 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  contiguous to (আ ুষ্ঠাঝ ক)্ছুাঁবয্আবছ্এম , সিংলগ্ন; প্রঝিবেশী; ঝ কটি। 
 ❑ contiguously (adverb)  
Examples:- 
 ❑ From an ecological point of view, the park should have encompassed contiguous biodiversity-rich forest tracts

 ❑ the 48 contiguous states

complex.

 ❑ Few detailed studies of large contiguous barley genomic sequences have been published. 
 ❑ Geographically my State is contiguous with both of them. 
 ❑ This has been mooted taking into account that a few places in the nearby villages beyond marsh are contiguous 
to the marsh. 

 

🎯 CONTINGENT ➺  ( kun TIN junt ) [ কানঝ্টনজ্ানট্্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  শিমসূচ্ক, সাবপক্ষ, সম্ভােয, অ‍ঝ ঝিি, অ‍ঝ যি, আকঝস্মক, শিমসাবপক্ষ, ঝ ভমরশীল

 ❑ Our agreement to buy their house is contingent upon the sell ers’ find ing another house to move

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ My hap pi ness is contingent on yours; if you’re unhappy, I’m unhappy. 
 ❑ The Bowdens were prepared for any contingency. Their front hall closet con tained a first-aid kit, a

 ❑ A contingency is a possibility or something that may happen but is at least as likely not to happen. 
 ❑ Several contingencies stand be tween us and the suc cess ful comple tion of our business proposal; 
several things could happen to screw it up.

🎯 COUP ➺  ( koo ) [ কূ]

 ❑ The student council’s great coup was persuading Foo Fighters to play at our prom. 
 ❑ In the attempted coup in the Philippines, some army officers tried to take over the government. 
 ❑ The full name for this type of coup is coup d’état (koo day TAH). A coup de grace (koo duh GRAHS) 
is a final blow or concluding event. 
 ❑ Note carefully the pronunciation of these words.  
Synonyms:- action, battle, bull's eye, confederation, dealing, decolonization, engagement, flying colors, 
hit, home run, internationalisation, legalization, military action, nonattendance, procession, score, 
seduction, smash, social control, vote 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 (plural coup s [কূজ্]্)্(ফরাঝস)্অ‍ভুযত্থা ; ক্ষমিা দখ্বলর্উবেবশয্আকঝস্মক্পদবক্ষপ্গ্র্হণ। 
 ❑ coup ď état [কূবদইিা:] সঝহিংস্অ‍থো্অ‍সািংঝেিাঝ ক্পদ্ধঝিবি্সরকার্পঝরেিম ্(বযম ্সামঝরক অ‍ভুযত্থা )। 
 ❑ coup de grâce [কূদা্গ্র্া:স্্America(n) কূদাগ্র্যাস্]্(ঝচ্বত্র)্দশষ্টা ্ো্দপাাঁচ্।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ he was overthrown in an army coup 
 ❑ Capturing him was a major coup for the Russians. 
 ❑ This development in turn would almost certainly provoke another military coup to prevent it from happening. 
 ❑ Independence came in 1957, and nine years later came the first military coup . 
 ❑ It doesn't necessarily happen all at once, or as the result of a traditional military coup d' état. 
 ❑ For some it was a massive publicity coup for the county town to host such a prestigious event.

🎯 CYNIC ➺  ( SIN ik ) [ ঝসঝ ক]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  শুভ াঝস্তক, অ‍সূযক

 ❑ When the pop star gave a million dollars to the museum, cynics said he was merely trying to buy 
himself a reputation as a cultured person. 
 ❑ To be cynical is to be extremely suspicious of the motivations of other peo ple. 
 ❑ Cynicism is general grumpiness and pessimism about human na ture.

joker, knocker, monster, pain in the neck, puke, scorner, scum bag, son of a bitch, squawker, swellhead,

Examples:-

🎯 DEFERENCE ➺  ( DEF ur uns ) [ দিফারানস্্,্ ঝিফাবরিা্]্

Word Smart Meaning:➭ n submission to another’s will; re spect; courte sy  
 ❑ To show deference to another is to place that person’s wishes ahead of your own. 
 ❑ Dean showed deference to his grandfather: He let the old man have first dibs on the birthday cake. 
 ❑ Danny stopped yodeling at the dinner table in deference to the wishes of his mother. 
 ❑ To show deference to another is to defer to that person. 
 ❑ Joe was supposed to go first, but he deferred to Steve, who had been wait ing longer. 
 ❑ To show deference is also to be deferential (def uh REN shul). 
 ❑ Joe was being def er en tial when he allowed Steve to go first.  
Synonyms:- respect, respectfulness, dutifulness, submissiveness, submission, obedience, surrender, 
accession, capitulation, acquiescence, complaisance, obeisance 
Antonyms:- defiance, disobedience, intractability, recalcitrance, disrespect 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 [uncountable noun] অ‍ব যর্ইচ্ছার্কাবছ্ ঝিস্বীকার; অ‍ব যর্মিামি্গ্র্াহযকরণ; মা যত্ব; েশেঝিমিা; সম্মা ; েদ্ধা:্to

🎯 DEPRECATE ➺  ( DEP ruh kayt ) [ দিপ্রাবকইট্, দিঝপ্রবকট্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  প্রাথম া্কঝরযা্দরাদ্কঝরোর্দচ্ষ্টা, অ‍সম্মঝি্করা, সায্ া্দদওযা, অ‍ ুবমাদ ্ া্করা, মৃদু্ঝেরঝি্প্রকাশ্করা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to express disapproval of  
 ❑ To deprecate a colleague’s work is to risk making yourself unwel come in your colleague’s office. 
 ❑ “This stinks!” is a deprecating remark. 
 ❑ The critic’s deprecating comments about my new novel put me in a bad mood for an entire month. 
 ❑ To be self-deprecating is to make little of one’s own efforts, often in the hope that some one else will 
say, “No, you’re swell!” 
 ❑ A very similar word is depreciate (dih PREE shee ayt). To de pre ci ate a col league’s work would be 
to represent it as being of little value. For another mean ing of depreciate, see appreciate.  
Synonyms:- belittle, deflate, denigrate, depreciate, derogate, deter, discourage, discredit, disgrace, 
minimize, object, pan, puncture, tear apart, trash, vilipend 
Antonyms:- acclaim, applaud, exalt, glorify, laud, magnify, praise, approve 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (verb transitive) (আ ুষ্ঠাঝ ক)্অ‍প্রসন্নিা্দোি্ও প্রকাশ্করা; অ‍ ুবমাদ ্ া্করা:্We deprecate changing the 
membership rules without consulting the general members. 
 ❑ deprecation [দিপ্রবকইশন্]্্(noun) অ‍  ুবমাদ ; অ‍প্রসাদ; ঝেঝপ্রযিা।

Synonyms:- reserved, shy, timid, unsure 
Antonyms:- immodest, outgoing, brash

🎯 DIGRESS ➺  ( dye GRES ) [ িাইবগ্র্স্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  মূল্গঝিপথ্দথবক্সবর্যাওযা, মূল্ঝেষয্দছবড়্েলা্ো্দলখ্া, অ‍প্রাসঝঙ্গক্হত্তযা, অ‍োন্তর্হত্তযা, মূল্গঝিপথ্দথবক্
সবর্যাওযা, মূল্ঝেষয্দছবড় েলা্ো্দলখ্া   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ v to stray from the main subject  
 ❑ Speaking met a phor i cal ly, to digress is to leave the main high way in order to travel aimlessly on 
back roads. When a speaker di gress es, he departs from the main topic and tells a story only dis tant ly 
related to it. 
 ❑ Such a story is called a digression. Some times a writer’s or speak er’s di gres sions are more 
interesting than his or her main points. 
 ❑ After a lengthy digression, the lecturer returned to his speech and brought it to a conclusion.

Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

Examples:-

of Italy.

brother, where the young boy is able to speak like a particularly eloquent adult.

thus enables a fuller, even more •coherent presentation of a subject.

🎯 DISCRIMINATE ➺  ( dih SKRIM uh nayt ) [ ঝিস্ঝ্ক্রঝমব ইট্, ঝিস্ঝ্ক্রঝমব ট্]্

a practice is not dis crim i nat ing (which is good), but discriminatory (which is wrong). 
 ❑ Indiscriminate means not discriminating; in other words, random or hap haz ard.

 ❑ You won’t find that kind of tree in California; it’s endemic to our part of the country. 
 ❑ That peculiar strain of influenza was endemic to a small commu ni ty in South Carolina; there were 
no cases anywhere else. 
 ❑ The writer Tom Wolfe coined the term “Me Decade” to de scribe the egocentricity endemic in the 
1970s.  
Synonyms:- endemic disease, endemical 
Antonyms:- cosmopolitanecdemicepidemic 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 , দকাব া্হদঝশক; আঞ্চঝলক্ো্দপশার্সবঙ্গ্যুি দরাগঝেবশষ।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Leishmaniasis should be considered in any person from an endemic area who has chronic localized skin 
lesions. 
 ❑ Shortages have become endemic to many regions, as record drought and population sprawl sap rivers and 
aquifers. 
 ❑ Yet it is also a global hot spot of biodiversity, with scores of endemic species of amphibians, birds, mammals, 
plants, and reptiles. 
 ❑ And there is no doubt the endemic poverty in the country is a barrier to innovation. 
 ❑ The Nene (also called Hawaiian) goose is Hawaii's state bird and endemic to the islands. 
 ❑ complacency is endemic in industry today 
 ❑ It is indicated for use in laboratory workers involved with the virus and in persons planning to travel to endemic 
areas. 
 ❑ Why is political stability so elusive, and why are violence and rights violations so endemic ? 
 ❑ Examples calling for immunization include travel to endemic areas or intravenous drug use during pregnancy. 
 ❑ In endemic areas the World Bank and others widely promote routine regular mass treatment of children with 
anthelmintics 
 ❑ All four species are endemic to Madagascar and are found primarily in rainforests.

ম ভাে, প্রশাঝন্ত, মব র্ো্দমজাবজর্সমিা অ‍থো্িীরিা

 ❑ The entire apartment building was crumbling, but Rachel faced the di sas ter with equanimity. She 
ducked out of the way of a falling beam and made herself a chocolate sundae. 
 ❑ John’s mother looked at the broken glass on the floor with equa nim i ty; at least he didn’t hurt 
himself when he knocked over the vase.  
Synonyms:- composure, calm, level-headedness, self-possession, coolheadedness, presence of mind, 
serenity, tranquility, phlegm, imperturbability, equilibrium, poise, assurance, self-confidence, aplomb,

Antonyms:- agitation, discomposure

 ❑ Equity is fairness; inequity is un fair ness. Iniquity and inequity both mean unfair, but iniquity

🎯 EQUIVOCAL ➺  ( ih KWIV uh kul ) [ ইবকাঝযভাকল্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  সবন্দহজ ক, িযথমক, িযথমযুি, িযথম, উভযাথম, সঝন্দগ্ধ, সবন্দহজ ক্অ‍থমপূণম, সবন্দহপূণম, অ‍ঝ ঝিি, অ‍ঝিরসঙ্কল্প, িাথমক,

Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj ambiguous; in ten tion al ly con fus ing; ca pa ble of be ing in ter pret ed in 
more than one way  
 ❑ Ambiguous means unclear. To be equivocal is to be in ten tion al ly am big u ous.  
 ❑ Joe’s response was equivocal; we couldn’t tell wheth er he meant yes or no, which is precisely what Joe 
wanted. 
 ❑ Dr. Festen’s equivocal diagnosis made us think that he had no idea what Mrs. Johnson had. 
 ❑ To be equivocal is to equivocate. To equivocate is to mislead by say ing con fus ing or ambiguous 
things. 
 ❑ When we asked Harold whether that was his car that was parked in the middle of the hardware store, 
he equivocated and asked, “In which aisle?”  
Synonyms:- ambiguous, indefinite, noncommittal, vague, imprecise, inexact, inexplicit, hazy, unclear, 
cryptic, enigmatic, pettifogging, ambivalent, uncertain, unsure, indecisive 
Antonyms:- certain, incontestable, indisputable, indubitable, sure, undeniable, undoubted, 
unquestionable, unequivocal

🎯 FACILE ➺  ( FAS il ) [ ফযাসাইল, ফযাস্ল্]্

📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS

ty.

of sexual fidelity . 
 ❑ Relationship experiences included status, selectiveness with partners, importance of steady partners, fidelity , 
and communication. 
 ❑ Both male and female adult polar bears captured in Manitoba and Ontario showed a high degree of fidelity over 
time to locations on shore. 
 ❑ he sought only the strictest fidelity to justice 
 ❑ Females demonstrate strong fidelity to the sites where they hatched, and they lead their mates back to those 
sites in the spring. 
 ❑ the 1949 recording provides reasonable fidelity 
 ❑ The result is maximum fidelity : a picture whose clarity, brilliance and color must be seen to be believed. 
 ❑ To demonstrate fidelity to the deceased family member, a band of wind and percussion instruments is often 
present to perform both traditional and popular music. 
 ❑ Muldoon's fidelity to his beliefs was considerable, but came to be compromised. 

 

🎯 FIGURATIVE ➺  ( FIG yur uh tiv ) [ ঝফগযারাঝটভ, ঝফগাবরঝটভ্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝেঝশষ্ট, আলঙ্কাঝরক, অ‍লঙ্কারপূণ,ম  লাক্ষঝণক, গালভরা, অ‍লঙ্কারেন্থল, আলিংকাঝরক, আদশমিা ীয, শব্দালিংকারঝপ্রয, 
শব্দালিংকারপূণম, প্রিীকী   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj based on figures of speech; ex press ing some thing in terms usually used for 
something else; met a phor i cal  
 ❑ When the mayor said that the housing market had sprouted wings, he was speaking figuratively. The 
housing market hadn’t really sprout ed wings; it had merely risen so rapidly that it had almost seemed to 
fly. 
 ❑ To say that the autumn hillside was a blaze of color is to use the word blaze in a figurative sense. The 
hillside wasn’t really on fire, but the colors of the leaves made it appear (somewhat) as though it were. 
 ❑ A figurative meaning of a word is one that is not literal. A literal statement is one in which every 
word means exactly what it says. If the housing market had literally sprouted wings, gen u ine wings 
would some how have popped out of it. 
 ❑ People very, very often confuse these words, using one when they really mean the other. 
 ❑ Desmond could literally eat money if he chewed up and swallowed a dollar bill. Desmond’s car eats 
money only fig u ra tive ly, in the sense that it is very expensive to operate.  
Synonyms:- metaphorical, nonliteral, symbolic, allegorical, representative, emblematic 

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 

Antonyms:- literal 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (শব্দ্ও্ভাষাসম্পঝকমি)্আলিংকাঝরক; আক্ষঝরি্অ‍বথম্ য েরিং্অ‍ য্অ‍বথম্(কল্প াঝেি্অ‍বথম)্[যথা্fiery শবব্দর্অ‍থম্‘অ‍ঝগ্নময’্
 া-েুঝিবয ‘ঝখ্বটঝখ্বট’্দোিাব া]। 
 ❑ figuratively (adverb)  
Examples:- 
 ❑ The son of a milkman, his grandmother provided early inspiration, a figurative painter who copied the likes of 
Turner. 
 ❑ Originally from Brisbane, Australia, Mark, is a figurative sculptor working in bronze. 
 ❑ On the contrary at any given point of time an abstract artist could do figurative work. 
 ❑ For example, is the term metaphor itself literal or figurative ? 
 ❑ Freud is better known as a figurative painter but his early paintings, often linear in character, owe much to his 
graphic work. 
 ❑ gold, in the figurative language of the people, was “the tears wept by the sun.” 
 ❑ Born in Spain, she has become a top figurative artist who interprets the everyday world of Spanish women. 
 ❑ A figurative painter throughout his career, Beckmann depicted the world around him with an unparalleled 
intensity. 
 ❑ Plenty of people are \"married to their jobs\" in a figurative sense. 
 ❑ Duncan creates elegant female forms and her work is figurative 
 ❑ though not representational.

🎯 FLOUT ➺  ( flowt ) [ ফ্লাউট্]

🎯 GAUCHE ➺  ( gohsh ) [ দগাউশ]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  আ াঝড়, কদযম, কদাকার, অ‍ঝেবেচ্ক, অ‍ঝশষ্ট, দকৌশলহী , দকৌশলশূ য, দকৌশলহী , দকৌশলশূ য, পঝরঝিঝি্ো্দলাক্
েুবি্কথা্েলার্ো্আচ্রণ্করার ক্ষমিােঝজমি্দলাকেযেহার-অ‍পুট, কান্ডজ্ঞা হী , দেআবক্কল, অ‍প্রস্তুি, আ াঝড়, অ‍ভেয   
Word Smart Meaning: adj unskillful; awkward; maladroit  
 ❑ Remember dextrous? Well, gauche is pretty much the exact opposite. It is the French word for left—
the connection is that left-handed people were once thought to be clumsy (this was clearly before the 
invention of left-handed scissors) and perverse, even evil. These days, gauche tends to describe social, 
rather than physical, ineptness. 

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ Smadar had a poor sense of comic timing, and her gauche attempts to mock her left-handed friends 
soon left her with none.  
Synonyms:- awkward, gawky, inelegant, graceless, ungraceful, ungainly, maladroit, klutzy, inept, lacking 
in social grace(s), unsophisticated, uncultured, uncultivated, unrefined, raw, inexperienced, unworldly 
Antonyms:- graceful, suave, urbane

🎯 GRATUITOUS ➺  ( gruh TOO uh tus ) [ গ্র্যাঝটউইটাস্,্ গ্র্যাঝটউইটূস্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍তেিঝ ক, অ‍যাঝচ্ি্সিংোদ, ঝভঝত্তহী , প্রমাণহী , খ্যরািী, ঝে ামূবলয্প্রদত্ত, একিরফা্উপকারসািক, অ‍কারণ,

 ❑ Their attack against us was gratuitous; we had never done anything to offend them. 
 ❑ Gratuitous is often misunderstood be cause it is con fused with gratu ity. A gratuity is a tip, like the 
one you leave in a res tau rant. A gratuity is a nice thing. Gra tu itous, however, is not nice. Don’t 
confuse these words.  
Synonyms:- unjustified, uncalled for, unwarranted, unprovoked, undue, indefensible, unjustifiable,

legendary - he lives alone in London.

 ❑ she avoided social gatherings in which there was too much gossip, observing that such conversation was at best 
unhelpful. 
 ❑ I am a fairly gregarious person, but I am quite comfortable in my own company. 
 ❑ Caspian Terns are less gregarious than other terns, nesting in smaller colonies, although this is changing in 
Washington. 
 ❑ The last gregarious flowering of muli bamboo in Mizoram, Tripura, Manipur and Barak Valley of Assam was 
reported in 1958-59 and was followed by famine in those areas.
