 ❑ The old men felt vulnerable and unwanted outside the her met ic security of their club.

Examples:-

stranger?

impenetrability of his most important works. 
 ❑ It has been observed often enough that references became increasingly obscure and hermetic in the nineteenth

 ❑ The hermetic obscurantism of these older texts repels a more casual reader, steeped as they are in

🎯 INDIGNANT ➺  ( in DIG nunt ) [ ইনল্ঝিগ ্ানট্]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍িুযগ্র্, ঘৃণাঝমঝেি্দক্রািযুি, অ‍কৃিজ্ঞিা, রুষ্ট, অ‍বযাগযিা, ঘৃণাঝমঝেি, দরাষাঝেষ্ট, ঝিক্কারপূণম, দক্রািযুি   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj angry, especially as a result of some thing unjust or unworthy; insulted  
 ❑ Ted became indignant when the policewoman accused him of steal ing the nuclear weapon. 
 ❑ Isabel was indignant when we told her all the nasty things that Blake had said about her over the 
public address system.  
Synonyms:- aggrieved, resentful, affronted, disgruntled, displeased, cross, angry, mad, annoyed, offended, 
exasperated, irritated, piqued, nettled, in high dudgeon, chagrined, peeved, vexed, irked, put out, miffed, 
aggravated, riled, in a huff, huffy, ticked off, sore 
Antonyms:- delighted, pleased 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  ঝেবশষি্অ‍ঝেচ্ার্ঝকিংো্অ‍ যায্অ‍পোবদর্কারবণ্কু্রদ্ধ্ও অ‍েজ্ঞাপূণম; রুষ্ট; কু্ষব্ধ:্at a false accusation; indignant 
with a treacherous friend. 
 ❑ indignantlyসবক্ষাবভ্ইিযাঝদ।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ She laughs indignantly and brings me back to earth. 
 ❑ He was indignant that we would even suggest that he was dirty. 
 ❑ There was angry and indignant protest from two out of three mentioned. 
 ❑ Malcolm saw the indignant and angry expression on her face change to he wasn't quite sure. 
 ❑ It would be too late to stride by, nose held high and glowing with indignant dislike, I had already said hello. 
 ❑ he was indignant at being the object of suspicion

home. 
 ❑ Consequently, Tessa wrote an angry and indignant letter to this newspaper denying that she had said any such 
thing.

 ❑ like my laptop is wilfully ignoring me.

🎯 INERT ➺  ( in URT ) [ ই াট্]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝ িল, িাের, গঝিহী , জড়, অ‍সাড়, প্রঝিবরাি-ক্ষমিাহী , অ‍লস, মন্থর, ঝ ঝষ্ক্রয, িৎপরিাহী , কুাঁবড়, অ‍প্রঝিবরািী, 
ঝ ঝষ্ক্রয   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj inactive; sluggish; not reacting chem i cal ly  
 ❑ The baseball team seemed strangely inert; it was as though they had lost the will not only to win but 
also to play. 
 ❑ Having colds made the children inert and reluctant to get out of bed. 
 ❑ Helium is an inert gas: It doesn’t burn, it doesn’t explode, and it doesn’t kill you if you inhale it. 
 ❑ To be inert is to be characterized by inertia. As it is most com mon ly used, inertia means lack of 
get-up-and-go, or an inability or un will ing ness to move. 
 ❑ In physics, inertia refers to an object’s tendency to continue do ing what it’s doing (either mov ing or 
staying still) unless it’s acted on by some thing else.  
Synonyms:- unmoving, motionless, immobile, inanimate, still, stationary, static, dormant, sleeping, 
unconscious, comatose, lifeless, insensible, insensate, insentient, idle, inactive, underactive, sluggish, 
lethargic, indolent, stagnant, listless, torpid 
Antonyms:- active, alive, busy, employed, going, living, on, running, working, movingactive 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  ১্জড়; অ‍বচ্ি :্inert matter. 
 ❑ ২্সঝক্রয রাসাযঝ ক্গুণেঝজমি; ঝ ঝষ্ক্রয:্inert gases. 
 ❑ ৩্(বদহ্ও্মব )্ভারী্ও মন্থর; জড়; ঝ বিষ্ট। 
 ❑ inertia [ই াশা]্(noun) [uncountable noun] ১ জড়িা। 
 ❑ ২্(পদাথমঝেদযা)্জািয।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Because it is chemically inert , helium was not identified on Earth until some time later, in 1895. 
 ❑ Bromine even reacts with relatively inert elements such as platinum and palladium. 
 ❑ So is it just an unwillingness on the part of an inert legal community in this country that the jury system has not 
been adequately researched?

his wife Lisa, has organised the free event.

to acid, base, and ketone exposure. 
 ❑ she lay inert in her bed

🎯 INFER ➺  ( in FUR ) [ ইনফ্া(র)]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍েিারণ্করা, আভাঝসি্করা, ঝসদ্ধান্ত্ো্িারণায্উপ ীি্হওযা, ঝসদ্ধান্ত্করা, অ‍ ুমা ্করা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  v to conclude; to deduce  
 ❑ Raizel said she loved the brownies, but I inferred from the size of the piece left on her plate that she 
had actually de spised them. 
 ❑ She hadn’t heard the score, but the silence in the locker room led her to infer that we had lost. 
 ❑ Infer is often confused with imply. To imply something is to hint at it, suggest it, or state it 
indirectly. To infer something is to figure out what it is without being told directly. 
 ❑ An inference is a deduction or conclusion.  
Synonyms:- deduce, conclude, conjecture, surmise, reason, interpret, gather, understand, presume, 
assume, take it, extrapolate, read between the lines, figure (out), reckon 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (verb transitive) (inferred, inferring, infers) infer (from something) (that...) অ‍ ুমা ্করা; ঝসদ্ধাবন্ত্আসা:্
We can infer from what he said that he is innocent. 
 ❑ inference [ইনফ্ারানস্্]্ (noun) ১্[uncountable noun] অ‍ ুমা ; উপপঝত্ত; অ‍ ুঝমঝি:্by inference, অ‍ ুমা ঝসদ্ধভাবে।

🎯 JUDICIOUS ➺  ( joo DISH us ) [ জূঝিশাস্]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  পঝরমাণদশমী, সুঝেজ্ঞ, জ্ঞা ী, সুঝেচ্ারপূণম, িীর, ঝেচ্ক্ষণ, সুদূরদশমী, ঝেবেচ্ক, প্রেীণ, খ্াাঁঝট   
Word Smart Meaning:➭ adj exercising sound judgment  
 ❑ The judge was far from judicious; he told the jury that he thought the defendant looked guilty and 
said that anyone who would wear a red bow tie into a courtroom deserved to be sent to jail. 
 ❑ The firefighters made judicious use of flame-retardant foam as the burning airplane skidded along the 
runway. 
 ❑ The mother of twin boys ju di cious ly used an elec tron mi cro scope and a laser to divide the ice 
cream into equal parts. 
 ❑ The word judicial is obviously closely related, but there is a crit i cal ly important difference in 
meaning between it and jud ic ious. A judge is judicial simply by virtue of being a judge; judicial means 
hav ing to do with judges, judgment, or justice. But a judge is judicious only if he or she ex er cis es sound 
judg ment.

 ❑ The legacy of the corrupt administration was chaos, bank rupt cy, and despair. 
 ❑ A shoebox full of baseball cards was the dead man’s only lega cy.  
 ❑ To be a legacy at a college sorority is to be the daughter of a former sorority member.  
Synonyms:- award, bestowal, borough english, bride price, contribution, donation, dowry, economic aid, 
economic assistance, enrichment, financial aid, financial assistance, free lunch, freebee, gift horse, 
giveaway, lagniappe, portion, present, prize

🎯 LIBEL ➺  ( LYE bul ) [ লাইবল্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝলবখ্্কুৎসা্প্রচ্ার, পরঝ ন্দা, ঝেবিষপূণম্কুৎসা্প্রচ্ার, পরঝ ন্দা্করা, কুৎসা্করা, েযঙ্গ্করা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  n a written or published falsehood that in jures the rep u ta tion of, or defames, 
someone  
 ❑ The executive said that the newspaper had committed libel when it called him a stinking, no-good, 
corrupt, in com pe tent, over paid, lying, worthless moron. He claimed that the news pa per had libeled 
him, and that its de scrip tion of him had been li bel ous. At the trial, the jury dis agreed, saying that the 
news pa per’s description of the executive had been sub stan tial ly accurate. 
 ❑ Don’t confuse this word with liable, which has an entirely different meaning. 
 ❑ Slander is just like libel except that it is spoken instead of written. 
 ❑ To slander someone is to say something untrue that injures that per son’s reputation.  
Synonyms:- assassinate, badmouth, drag through the mud, malign, traduce, assassination, blackwash, 
character assassination, epithet, malignment, name, name calling, names, slander, smear, vilification 
Antonyms:- praise 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

newspaper for libel; utter or publish libel against somebody. 
 ❑ ২্[countable noun] libel on (কথয)্কাবরা্কুৎসা্ো্িার্প্রঝি্ঝেবিষপূণম মন্তেয। 
 ❑ □(verb transitive) (libelled, libelling, libels, America(n) libeled, libeling, libels) কাবরা্ঝ ন্দাোদপূণম্ঝকছু্
প্রকাশ করা। 
 ❑ libellous (America(n) libelous) [লাইবেলাস্]্্(adjective) কুৎসাপূণম, কুৎসাজ ক:্a libellous journal/article.  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Maybe we could better ourselves by reaching out to others - and help kill a poisonous libel at the same time. 
 ❑ a libel action 
 ❑ Britain's libel laws are almost the opposite of those in the United States. 
 ❑ she alleged the magazine had libeled her 
 ❑ A third common law offence which may involve strict liability is that of blasphemous libel . 
 ❑ A statement that a police officer is under is investigation is no doubt defamatory, but the sting in the libel is not 
as sharp as the statement that he has by his conduct brought suspicion on himself. 
 ❑ The extent of publication is also very relevant: a libel published to millions has a greater potential to cause 
damage than a libel published to a handful of people. 
 ❑ Despite the recommendations of the Faulks Committee, the law of defamation still distinguishes between libel 
and slander. 
 ❑ As Robertson circulated his pamphlet where he could, the matter was a serious libel .

 ❑ His lawyer thought a lawsuit would be fruitless, but the client wanted to litigate. He was feeling

 ❑ When the company was unable to recover its money out side of court, its only option was to litigate.

Synonyms:- action, appeal, call into question, call one's bluff, call out, counterchallenge, dare, defy,

 ❑ litigation[ঝলঝটবগইশন্]্্(noun) [uncountable noun] মামলা; আইব র্আেয্গ্র্হণ।

Examples:- 
 ❑ They do not need a power which deprives a litigant of his right to litigate .

proceeding. 
 ❑ the plaintiff is prepared to litigate

tribunal in fact has jurisdiction under the convention.

basis that they commenced a class proceeding. 
 ❑ One does not take away that choice by permitting, encouraging or preventing the exhortation of the citizen to 
litigate or not to litigate . 
 ❑ After all, the very reason why parties conclude an arbitration agreement is because they do not wish to litigate in 
the Courts. 
 ❑ The jurisdiction point having been abandoned by negotiations, the parties would have been free to litigate in 
whatever jurisdiction was willing to accept jurisdiction for the proceedings.

 ❑ Both genres are based on stories of different kinds of martial quest. 
 ❑ He has done a great service in bringing more attention to the western martial tradition and history. 
 ❑ In the opening part there are fight scenes woven around him to introduce us to his martial skills. 
 ❑ There are few stunts and only rudimentary fight sequences, dependent upon fire power rather than martial 
artistry.

🎯 MAVERICK ➺  ( MAV ur ik ) [ মযাভাঝরক]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  োউণু্ডবল, ভেঘুবর, যাযাের   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  n a nonconformist; a rebel  
 ❑ The word maverick originated in the Old West. It is derived from the name of Samuel A. Maverick, a 
Texas banker who once accepted a herd of cattle in payment of a debt. Maverick was a banker, not a 
rancher. He failed to confine or brand his calves, which habitually wandered into his neighbors’ pastures. 
Local ranchers got in the habit of referring to any unbranded calf as a maverick. The word is now used 
for anyone who has refused to be “branded”—who has refused to con form. 
 ❑ The political scientist was an intellectual maverick; most of his the o ries had no followers except 
himself. 
 ❑ Maverick can also be an adjective. 
 ❑ The maverick police offic er got in trouble with the department for using illegal means to track down 
crim i nals.  
Synonyms:- beat, beatnik, bohemian, dogie, dogy, enfant terrible, heretic, leppy, rebel, irregular, 
unconventional, unorthodox 
Antonyms:- conformist 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 (America(n)) ১্মাঝলবকর্ছাপঝেহী ্অ‍েিায্পবথ্পবথ্ঘুবর দেড়ায্এম ্দগােৎস; (লাক্ষঝণক)্পবথ্পবথ্ঘুবর্দেড়ায্এম ্
দলাক। 
 ❑ ২্দগাাঁড়া  য্এম ্দলাক:্He is a maverick person.  
Examples:- 
 ❑ The first is a private sketchbook, posthumously made public at a time when attention was turning again to this 
American maverick . 
 ❑ He is one of the few truly great, genuinely maverick songwriters and performers of the present day. 
 ❑ All I know is that MPs are very maverick so expect to be surprised! 
 ❑ a maverick among Connecticut Republicans 
 ❑ I spent a few hours scratching my head and looking for a cryptic code which might shed light on where this 
maverick genius is getting his ideas from. 
 ❑ His face displays a limited emotional range and, at times, his portrayal of the maverick scientist is boring. 
 ❑ While I admire maverick clergymen, it takes the guts of the ‘ordinary’ man to go about doing good and decent 
deeds daily without fanfare. 
 ❑ There is a slow stirring of revolt that goes far beyond fuel protests and maverick votes for television presenters.

Antonyms:- real

 🗹 (যুঝি্ইিযাঝদ)্প্রকৃি্কারণ্দগাপ ্করার্দচ্ষ্টায উপিাপ ্করা্হবযবছ্এম ; দলাকবদখ্াব া; োহযি্প্রিীযমা ; আপাি। 
 ❑ ostensibly [অ‍বস্টনস্আবঝ্ল]্(adverb)  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Later, the company risked its stance of ostensible objectivity by joining the preacher and his family for a picnic 
supper at a farm north of the city. 
 ❑ It is, after all, made up of ostensible competitors who are allied for the common good.

passenger of different faiths. 
 ❑ the delay may have a deeper cause than the ostensible reason 
 ❑ The safety team's ostensible goal was, if possible, to manage the project to a safe and successful conclusion. 
 ❑ A biography of Elvire O'Connor, the ostensible writer of this piece, is included in the program and is a tiny work 
of art in its own right. 
 ❑ There is a remarkable piece of dialogue on just this subject in Dr Faustus, although the ostensible topic is music. 
 ❑ The ostensible reason is that he does not wish to relinquish his seat in the European parliament. 
 ❑ While the ostensible motivation will be to improve the security of the Internet, the real objective will be to 
increase corporate profitability.

সিয, কথা্আপাি্সিযঝেদবরািী মব ্হবলও্োস্তঝে্সিয

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ One of Xeno’s paradoxes seems to prove the im pos si bil i ty of an ar row’s ever reaching its target: If 
the arrow first moves half the distance to the target, then half the remaining dis tance, then half the 
remaining dis tance, and so on, it can never ar rive. 
 ❑ A paradox is par a dox i cal.

taster.

work full of paradox and ambiguity.

visitors he had.

with a problem.  
Examples:- 
 ❑ He's a paradox in some ways. There is an air of indifference, but he really does care.

 ❑ a potentially serious conflict between quantum mechanics and the general theory of relativity known as the 
information paradox 
 ❑ cathedrals face the paradox of having enormous wealth in treasures but huge annual expenses

 ❑ Solo practice improves concentration, which improves group practice. This sounds like a paradox 
 ❑ but it is not.

to create the new. 
 ❑ It sounds like a paradox - Paris has almost three times as much rain as London but London is much rainier than 
Paris. 
 ❑ the liar paradox

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝেকারিি, দরাগঝেদযা, দরাগঝ দা -িি, ঝেকারিত্ব, দরাদঝেদযা, ঝ দা -শাস্ত্র   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  n the science of diseases  
 ❑ Pathology is the science or study of diseases, but not nec es sar i ly in the medical sense. 
Pathological means relating to pathology, but it also means arising from a disease. So if we say Brad is 
an in vet er ate, in cor ri gi ble, patho log i cal (path uh LAHJ uh kul) liar, we are saying that Brad’s lying 
is a sick ness.  
Synonyms:- alkalosis, anchylosis, angiopathy, asynergy, azymia, biliousness, cartilaginification, 
disfunction, endometriosis, gangrene, hemochromatosis, illness, iron overload, lithiasis, macrocytosis, 
neuropathy, pyorrhea, serology, sickness, softness

 ❑ pathologically [পাথলাঝজঝি]  
Examples:-

 ❑ Far from virtue, this is pathology 
 ❑ behavior that serves neither the self nor others.

 ❑ Semiquantitative analysis of lung pathology confirmed these changes.

🎯 PERUSE ➺  ( puh ROOZ ) [ পারূজ্]্

to back out of the deal. 
 ❑ To pe ruse something is to engage in perusal. 
 ❑ My perusal of the ancient texts brought me no closer to my goal of discovering the meaning of life.  
Synonyms:- read, study, scrutinize, inspect, examine, wade through, look through, browse through, leaf 
through, scan, run one's eye over, glance through, flick through, skim through, thumb through, dip into

his client.

🎯 POIGNANT ➺  ( POYN yunt ) [ পযঝ যনট্্, পয যান্টা্]্

Antonyms:- unimpressive, unemotional

🎯 PRAGMATIC ➺  ( prag MAT ik ) [ প্রযাগম্যাঝটক, প্রযাগম্যাঝটক]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  রাজকীয্অ‍ ুশাস , রাষ্ট্রীয, রাষ্ট্রশাস সিংক্রান্ত, আত্মাঝভমা ী, কমমিৎপর, োস্তেিমমপ্রবযাগোদী, প্রবযাঝগক, প্রাবযাঝগক,

tar instead. 
 ❑ Pragmatism (PRAG muh tiz um) is the belief or philosophy that the value or truth of something can 
be measured by its practical con se quenc es.  
Synonyms:- pragmatic sanction, practical, matter-of-fact, sensible, down-to-earth, commonsensical, 
businesslike, having both/one's feet on the ground, hardheaded, no-nonsense, hard-nosed

🎯 PRECEDENT ➺  ( PRES uh dunt ) [ দপ্রঝসিানট্্, প্রীসীবিন্ট]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  পূেমেিমী্েস্তু্ো্ঝেষয, অ‍িীবির্উদাহরণ্ো্ ঝজর, রূল, উদাহরণ,  ঝজর, ঝ দশম , পূেম্ ঝজর্ো্দৃষ্টান্ত, পূেমেিমী্
েস্তু্ো্ঝেষয   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  n an earlier example or model of some thing Precedent is a noun form of the 
verb to precede, or go be fore. To set a precedent is to do something that sets an ex am ple for what may 
follow. 
 ❑ Last year’s million-dollar prom set a precedent that the current student council hopes will not be 
followed in the future. That is, the student council hopes that future proms won’t cost a million dollars. 
 ❑ To be unprecedented is to have no precedent, to be something en tire ly new. 
 ❑ Urvashi’s consumption of 10,677 hot dogs was un prec e dent ed; no one had ever eaten so many hot 
dogs before.  
Synonyms:- model, exemplar, example, pattern, previous case, prior instance/example, paradigm, 
criterion, yardstick, standard 
Antonyms:- after, ensuing, following, later, posterior, subsequent, succeeding 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  ঝজর; পূেমঝ দশম ; পূেমদৃষ্টান্ত। 
 ❑ set/create/establish a precedent (for something)  ঝজর/পূেমদৃষ্টান্ত িাপ /সৃঝষ্ট্করা। 
 ❑ precedented ঝজবরর্িারা্সমঝথমি।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ I shall add to the definition of humanly free agents, that they are agents whose choices do not have fully 
deterministic precedent causes. 
 ❑ Furthermore, this is a case of general importance and it may well set a precedent . 
 ❑ What a pleasing precedent any unlikely victory would set! 
 ❑ We all have to go through the same nonsense, which seems crazy considering the precedent set at the first 
hearing. 

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS

country. 
 ❑ breaking with all precedent 
 ❑ I want the kind of precedent I have seen in Europe followed here.

would be a precedent set.

 ❑ We fear there may well be a precedent set for the rest of her school life.

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS

could say that someone had stum bled down a precipitous slope into drug addiction.  
Synonyms:- steep, sheer, perpendicular, abrupt, sharp, vertical

 ❑ A preemptive action is one that is undertaken in order to prevent some other action from being 
undertaken. 
 ❑ When the air force launched a pre emp tive strike against the missile base, the air force was at tack 
ing the missiles in order to prevent the missiles from attacking the air force.

🎯 PREPOSSESS ➺  ( pree puh ZES ) [ প্রীপাবজস্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  পূবেমই্অ‍ঝিকার্করা, পক্ষপািী্করা, সমূ্পণমরূবপ্আচ্ছন্ন্করা, পূেমাবহ্নই্পক্ষপািপূণম্করা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  v to preoccupy; to influence be fore hand or prej u dice; to make a good

 ❑ This word has several common meanings. Be careful. 
 ❑ When a person is prepossessed by an idea, he or she can’t get it out of his or her mind. 
 ❑ My dream of producing energy from old chewing-gum wrappers pre pos sessed me, and I lost my job, 
my home, my wife, and my children. 
 ❑ Experience had prepossessed Larry’s mother not to believe him when he said that someone else had 
broken the win dow; Larry had broken it every other time, so she assumed that he had broken it this time. 
 ❑ The new girl in the class was extremely prepossessing. The minute she walked into the room, her 
classmates rushed over to introduce themselves. 
 ❑ Unprepossessing means unimpressive, but the word is only mild ly negative. 
 ❑ The quaint farmhouse had an unprepossessing ex te ri or, but a beau ti ful interior. Who would have 
imagined?  
Synonyms:- bias, blackjack, blackmail, carry, color, colour, dominate, fix, form, ghost, haunt, militate, 
persuade, predetermine, prejudice, pressure, pull strings, swing, swing over, wow

prepossessed by the young lady’s charms.

 🗹 [Countable noun] (ঝেবশষি্দকাব া্শাসবকর)্ঝেবশষ্অ‍ঝিকার; ঝেবশষাঝিকার; প্রাঝিকার:্the prerogative of pardon, 
দযম ্দঝণ্ডি্অ‍পরািীবক্ক্ষমা করার্অ‍ঝিকার। 
 ❑ the Royal Prerogative (British/Britain) সিংসদ ঝ রবপক্ষভাবে্কাজ্করার্(ঝ ছক্িাঝিক)্অ‍ঝিকার; রাজকীয্
ঝেবশষাঝিকার।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Previously, of course, literacy had been the exclusive prerogative of the clergy. 
 ❑ The honey seems extraordinarily expensive, but then sweetness was a prerogative of the rich until the 
eighteenth century. 
 ❑ No longer the prerogative of middle class matrons or ladies who lunch, a fabulous range of facilities is right here 
in Glasgow.

the standard practice up to now.

 ❑ In answering such a question, the executive enjoys no constitutional prerogative .

🎯 PREVAIL ➺  ( pri VAYL ) [ ঝপ্রবভইল, ঝপ্রবভল]্   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝেজযলাভ্করা, প্রেল্হওযা, চ্ালু্হওযা, লত্তযা , জযী হত্তযা, অ‍ঝিকির্প্রভােশালী্হত্তযা, প্রচ্ঝলি্হত্তযা, প্রাদুভূমি্

Word Smart Meaning:➭  v to triumph; to overcome rivals; (with on, upon, or with) to persuade  
 ❑ When justice prevails, it means that good defeats evil. 
 ❑ The prosecutor prevailed in the murder trial; the defendant was found guilty. 
 ❑ My mother prevailed on me to make my bed. She told me she would punish me if I didn’t, so I did. 
 ❑ The adjective pre vail ing means most frequent or predominant. The pre vail ing opinion on a topic is 
the one that most people hold. If the pre vail ing winds are out of the north, then the wind is out of the 
north most of the time. A prevailing theory is the one most widely held at the time. It is prevalent 
(PREV uh lunt).  
Synonyms:- win, win out/through, triumph, be victorious, carry the day, come out on top, succeed, prove 
superior, conquer, overcome, rule, reign 
Antonyms:- lose, fail

 ❑ We were provident with our limited food supplies, knowing that the winter ahead would be long and 
cold. 
 ❑ The provident father had long ago set aside money for the college education of each of his children. 
 ❑ To be improvident is to fail to provide for the future. 
 ❑ It was im prov i dent of the grasshopper not to store any food for the winter, unlike his ac quain tance 
the provident ant.  
Synonyms:- prudent, farsighted, judicious, shrewd, circumspect, forearmed, wise, sagacious, sensible, 
thrifty, economical 
Antonyms:- prodigal, profligate, squandering, improvident 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 ভঝেষযৎ্চ্াঝহদা; ঝেবশষি্োিমকযকালী ্প্রবযাজ ্দমটাব ার জ য্প্রস্তুি্ঝকিংো্ভঝেষযবির্চ্াঝহদা্সম্ববন্ধ্সিকম; দূরদশমী;

attended by more stu dents. 
 ❑ The difference between the two restaurants was quantitative rather than qualitative. Both served 
the same dreadful food, but the second res tau rant served more of it.

Antonyms:- quantitative

 ❑ The value of qualitative methods in researching patient attitudes is well recognised. 
 ❑ In this connection, the ability of an adjective to form degrees of comparison is usually taken as a formal sign of 
its qualitative character, in opposition to a relative adjective which is understood as incapable of forming degrees of 
comparison by definition. 
 ❑ a qualitative change in the undergraduate curriculum 
 ❑ Girls in the qualitative study reported more troubled and unstable families than boys. 
 ❑ The majority of studies rely on survey research alone and there appears to be little qualitative work.

 ❑ not merely quantitative.

 ❑ she became querulous and demanding 
 ❑ His classmates were repelled by his querulous and complaining statements. 

 

🎯 QUIXOTIC ➺  ( kwik SAHT ik ) [ কুইকস্ঝটক, কুইবক্সাঝটক]্   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ভােঝেলাসী, োস্তেজ্ঞা হী , অ‍িযঝিক্উদার   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj romantic or idealistic to a foolish or im prac ti cal degree  
 ❑ The word quixotic is derived from the name of Don Quixote, the pro tag o nist of Miguel de 
Cervantes’s classic seventeenth-century nov el. Don Quixote had read so many romances about the golden 
age of chivalry that he set out to become a knight himself and have chiv al rous adventures. Instead, his 
romantic idealism almost in vari ably got him into trouble. To be quixotic is to be as foolish or 
impractical as Don Quixote in pursuing an ideal. 
 ❑ For many years Mr. Morris had led a quixotic effort to repeal the federal income tax. 
 ❑ The political organization had once been a powerful force in Wash ing ton, but its membership had 
dwindled, and its causes had be come in creas ing ly quixotic.  
Synonyms:- idealistic, romantic, visionary, utopian, extravagant, starry-eyed, unrealistic, unworldly, 
impractical, impracticable, unworkable, impossible 
Antonyms:- clear-eyed, clear-sighted, down-to-earth 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 উচ্চ্অ‍থচ্্অ‍লীক্আদবশমর্অ‍ ুগামী; খ্ামবখ্যাঝল; আপ  স্বাথম্সম্পবকম্অ‍সবচ্ি ; পবরাপকারী। 
 ❑ quixotically (adverb)  

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
Examples:- 
 ❑ I am now a well behaved individual, I have cut down on my quixotic outings, though the prospect of getting 
fatally maimed on one of those windmills is always enticing. 
 ❑ They believe - perhaps quixotically , under some owners - that they work for the entire community, not just the 
stockholders. 
 ❑ Still, it also serves to accentuate the film's central point, that represented images often provide the basis of our 
hopes and dreams, no matter how quixotic those dreams may be. 
 ❑ It was unprecedented, quixotic and admirable. 
 ❑ If this doesn't seem quixotic enough in today's gruesome circumstances, he also has to confront religious parties 
on the city council and an inept central government that won't give him a serious budget. 
 ❑ a vast and perhaps quixotic project 
 ❑ It is an old-fashioned project, and a quixotic one, but deeply moving in its hope that Wyclif's Bible and Burns's 
songs form an inheritance we would all want, if only we knew about it. 
 ❑ She responded with a quixotic courage that eventually infected me; during her two-year illness, I'd grown less 
pessimistic both about her prognosis and about life itself. 
 ❑ His quixotic 
 ❑ idealist appeal for justice contrasts sharply with the rest of the exhibition, in which justice does not seem to be 
expected. 
 ❑ The truth is slippery, and plumbing the past to catch hold of it is as quixotic a quest as the search for the perfect 
bottle of wine, but it is a noble and necessary one. 

 
🎯 RAMIFICATION ➺  ( ram uh fuh KAY shun )

 ❑ The professor found a solution to the problem, but there are many ram i fi ca tions; some experts are 
afraid that he has created more prob lems than he has solved.  
Synonyms:- consequence, result, aftermath, outcome, effect, upshot, development, implication, product, 
by-product 
Examples:- 
 ❑ Many of us are still simply dismayed by recent events and troubled by their international ramifications .

 ❑ His core concept was ramification , meaning the likelihood that co-operation in one sector would lead 
governments to extend the range of collaboration across other sectors.

collaboration across other sectors.

 ❑ And he will be aware that the Senate results have ramifications for a long time to come.

🎯 RECONDITE ➺  ( REK un dyte ) [ দরকানি্াইট্]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  গূঢ়, দুবেমািয, প্রগাঢ়, দুবজ্ঞময, দুরঝিগময   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj hard to understand; over one’s head  
 ❑ The philosopher’s thesis was so recondite that I couldn’t get past the first two sentences. 
 ❑ Every now and then the pro fes sor would lift his head from his desk and deliver some recondite

 ❑ The scholarly jour nal was so recondite as to be utterly in com pre hen si ble. 
 ❑ Note carefully the pronunciation of this word.  
Synonyms:- abstruse, deep, esoteric 
Antonyms:- shallow, superficial, mainstream

general that transformed Europe between the four teenth and seventeenth centuries. The word is also used 
in con nec tion with lesser rebirths.

crumbling tenements and turned them into at trac tive apartment buildings. 
 ❑ The small college’s football team had endured many losing sea sons but underwent a dramatic 
renaissance when the new coach recruited half-a-dozen 400-pound freshmen. 
 ❑ Renaissance can also be spelled renascence (ri NAY suns).

ঝেবশষত্বিঃ্যুবদ্ধর ক্ষঝিপূরণস্বরূপপ্রদত্্ত্টাকাকঝড়্ইিযাঝদ

victorious army. 
 ❑ After the ac ci dent we sought reparation in court, but our law yer was not competent and we didn’t

 ❑ Something that cannot be repaired is irreparable (i REP uh ruh bul). Note carefully the

কলঙ্ক, গাঁজ া, মা হাঝ , অ‍খ্যাঝি, কলঙ্কর্ঝেষয, উপালম্ভ, গহমণ, পঝরোদ, গাল, অ‍ঝিবক্ষপ, ফইজি, অ‍ ুবযাগ, ঝ ন্দা্ো্ঝিরস্কার্

or accusingly. To be filled with selfreproach can mean to be ashamed.

 ❑ Even though Jerome did hit Mabel on the head, his motive was ir re proach able: He had merely been 
trying to kill a fly perched on her hairnet.

ঝ ন্দা্করা, টুকা, অ‍ ুবযাগ্করা, খু্ি িরা, দদাষবরাপ্করা, েকুঝ ্দদওযা

🎯 SACCHARINE ➺  ( SAK uh rin )   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  শকমরাপূণম, শকমরাসুলভ, অ‍সহযরকম্ঝমষ্ট, ঝচ্ঝ র্মি   

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 

Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj sweet; excessively or dis gust ing ly sweet Saccharin is a calorie-free 
sweetener; saccharine means sweet. Ex cept for the spelling, this is one of the easiest-to-remember words 
there is. 
 ❑ Saccharine can be applied to things that are literally sweet, such as sugar, saccharin, fruit, and so 
on. It can also be applied to things that are sweet in a figurative sense, such as children, per son al i ties, 
and sen ti ments—especially things that are too sweet, or sweet in a sick en ing way. 
 ❑ We wanted to find a nice card for Uncle Mo, but the cards in the display at the drugstore all had such 
saccharine mes sag es that we would have been too embarrassed to send any of them. 
 ❑ The love story was so saccharine that I vowed never to see another sappy, predictable movie again.  
Synonyms:- cloying, sweet, syrupy, treacly 
Antonyms:- bitter 
Examples:- 
 ❑ Thus the same saccharine solution may be made to undergo either the vinous or the butyric fermentation, 
according as the yeast plant or another organism, described by Pasteur, is introduced into it.

 ❑ I always find songs written about that quite saccharine and a little bit obvious.

easy listening. 
 ❑ Janice Beard is a sweet film that manages to avoid being too saccharine . 
 ❑ The sentimentality, which at times reaches unbearable levels, is saccharine and cloying. 
 ❑ Even during his well-documented years of excess, the saccharine sweetness of James Taylor's voice served him

📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS

 ❑ To be sagacious is to have sagacity (suh GAS uh tee). A similar word is sage, which means wise, 
possessing wisdom derived from ex pe ri ence or learning. 
 ❑ When we were contemplating starting our own popcorn business, we received some sage advice from a 
man who had lost all his money selling candied apples. 
 ❑ The professor’s critique, which comprised a few sage comments, sent me back to my room feeling 
pretty stupid. 
 ❑ Sage can also be a noun. A wise person, especially a wise old person, is often called a sage.

 ❑ Yet the interminable self-contemplation, articulate and sagacious though it is, proves to be a bit too much of a 
good thing, and this gray, humorless, dispassionate novel eventually sinks under the weight of it all.

was constantly in danger of slamming it in doors and windows.

vital, essential, pivotal, prime, central, paramount

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 

 ❑ □েঝহমুমখ্্দকাণ; শত্রুেূযবহর্উপর্সূঝচ্মুখ্্আক্রমবণর্িারা সৃষ্ট্ফাটল।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ What were the most salient features of the impeachment crisis and its most important political lessons? 
 ❑ The crisp presentation outlined all the salient features of broadband technology, notably cheaper downloads 
and smoother surfing. 
 ❑ He does not neglect the contribution of blues singers to the body of railroad songs, and in fact he discusses the 
salient features of the blues genre and its importance in commercial recordings. 
 ❑ Mill's salient distinction is between offence and harm its implications for political correctness are pellucid. 
 ❑ Their seal bore as its device a demi-fox salient , with a motto on a ribbon "Libert« toute enti•re". 
 ❑ it succinctly covered all the salient points of the case 
 ❑ One of the salient features of that newspaper is its excellent editorial page. 

 

🎯 SALUTARY ➺  ( SAL yuh ter ee ) [ সযাঝলযউঝট্র্, সযাঝলযউবটঝর]   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  শুভপ্রদ, মঙ্গলদাযক   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj healthful; remedial; cur a tive  
 ❑ Lowered blood pressure is among the salutary effects of exercise. 
 ❑ The long sea voyage was salutary; when Elizabeth landed she looked ten years younger than she had 
when she set sail.  
Synonyms:- good, healthful 
Antonyms:- bad, unfriendly, unprofitable 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 (শরীর্ও্মব র্জ য)্কলযাণকর; কলযাণেহ; ঝহিকর।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Vandell has an explanation for why these kinds of activities - such as art and music programs - have such 
salutary effects on kids. 
 ❑ He had been remanded in custody for a short period of time and that had had a salutary effect upon him. 
 ❑ The trial is bound to be a show - but a show that is much more likely to have salutary effects, on balance. 
 ❑ a salutary reminder of where we came from 
 ❑ The generous New Hope program had a particularly salutary academic effect on boys, the team found. 
 ❑ Disappointing as her father's edict was to her, it did have the salutary effect of keeping little Mary out of harm's 
way. 
 ❑ Although such measures enabled Cavour to outmanoeuvre the clerical right in the short run, their long-term 
effects were less salutary . 
 ❑ Kind words have just the opposite effect: They are salutary and healing because they offer encouragement and 
hope to others.

See apartheid.

🎯 SUBSTANTIVE ➺  ( SUB stan tiv ) [ সাবস্্ট্ানঝ্টভ্]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  োস্তে, িাযী, স্বিি, প্রকৃি, অ‍ঝস্তত্বেযজ্ঞা্জক, অ‍ িী , প্রচু্রপঝরমাণ, ঝেবশষয   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj having substance; real; es sen tial; sol id; sub stan tial  
 ❑ The differences between the two theories were not sub stan tive; in fact, the two theories said the 
same thing with different words. 
 ❑ The gossip columnist’s wild accusations were not based on any thing sub stan tive; her source was a

argue from what is found in one to what will probably be found in another; each has its own precedents.

different words. For example: 
 ❑ The trou ble with bach e lors is that they aren’t married.  
Synonyms:- pleonastic, prolix, redundant, tautologic 
Examples:-  Example  ➭✿In the sentence "It was visible to the eye," the phrase "to the eye" is tautological.

🎯 TRANSIENT ➺  ( TRAN shunt ) [ ট্র্যানঝ্জআনট্্, ট্র্যানশ্ন্ট্্, ট্র্যাঝিবযন্টা্]্

mendicants, and other homeless people are often called transients. 
 ❑ A very similar word is transitory, which means not lasting long. A transient breeze might provide 
transitory relief from the heat. 
 ❑ This word can also be pronounced TRAN zee unt.

🎯 UTILITARIAN ➺  ( yoo til uh TAR ee un ) [ ইঊঝটঝলবটআঝরআন]্   

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  উপবযাগোদী   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj stressing use ful ness or utility above all other qual i ties; pragmatic  
 ❑ Jason’s interior-decorating philosophy was strictly util i tar i an; if an ob ject wasn’t genuinely useful, 
he didn’t want it in his home. 
 ❑ Utilitarian can also be a noun. Jason, just aforementioned, could be called a utilitarian.  
Synonyms:- egalitarian, elitist, equalitarian, functional, useful, utile 
Antonyms:- useless 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 ১্সিয, সুন্দর্ও্কলযাবণর্দচ্বয্উপবযাঝগিার্উপর্অ‍ঝিক গুরুত্ব্আবরাপ্কবর্এম ; উপবযাগোদী। 
 ❑ ২্উপবযাগোদী্ও্িাবদর্আদশম সম্বন্ধীয; উপবযাগোদী। 
 ❑ □(noun) Utilitarian উপবযাগোবদর্সমথমক; উপবযাগোদী। 
 ❑ utilitarianism [ইঊঝটঝলবটআঝরঝ জাম]্্(noun) [uncountable noun] জীেব র্দশষ্ঠ্ঝেিা ্হবচ্ছ্‘সেমাঝিক্সিংখ্যক্
মা ুবষর্সেমাঝিক সুখ্’্ঝ ঝিি্করার্লবক্ষয্কাজ্করা-্এই্রাজত ঝিক্ও্দেবযা ীঝিক্মিোদ; উপবযাগোদ।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ It said the battle to save the building was lost and the site was now to be covered by flats of a utilitarian design. 
 ❑ Surprising though, is the toned down and rather utilitarian look and shape of the accessories. 
 ❑ Modern philosophers tend to take a more utilitarian position. 
 ❑ a utilitarian theorist 
 ❑ Stoneware was the basic ceramic ware for utilitarian objects in the nineteenth century. 
 ❑ In England, the utilitarian doctrine of a higher public good trumped the idea of intellectual property rooted in 
natural right. 
 ❑ These traditions provide inspiration at every level - from the design of the most utilitarian objects to fine art. 
 ❑ They used these simple stacked facades for unpretentious utilitarian buildings; the repeated detail lent itself to 
prefabrication. 
 ❑ It is a shopping centre, not Salisbury Cathedral, and it is always going to be a utilitarian building.

 ❑ A country where nobody had to work would be Quentin’s idea of utopia.

 ❑ A utopian is someone with unrealistic or impractical plans or ex pec ta tions for society. Such plans or 
expectations are utopian plans or expectations. ❉The opposite of a utopiais a dystopia.

🎯 VACILLATE ➺  ( VAS uh layt ) [ ভযাঝসবলইট্]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  দদালাযমা ্হওযা, চ্াঁচ্ল্হত্তযা, ঝির্ া্থাকা, টলা, ঝিিাগ্র্স্ত্হত্তযা, আবন্দাঝলি্হত্তযা, এঝদবক-ত্তঝদবক্হত্তযা, 
দদালাযমা  হত্তযা, করা, ইিস্তিিঃ্করা, এঝদক্ওঝদক্দদালাযমা , আবন্দাঝলি্হওযা, এঝদবক্-্ত্তঝদবক হত্তযা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  v to be indecisive; to waver  
 ❑ We invited James to spend Thanksgiving with us, but he vac il lat ed for so long that we finally 
became annoyed and disinvited him. 
 ❑ Tyler vacillated about buying a new car. He couldn’t decide wheth er to get one. 
 ❑ The act of vacillating is called vacillation.  
Synonyms:- dither, waver, be indecisive, be undecided, be ambivalent, hesitate, be of two minds, blow hot 
and cold, keep changing one's mind, be conflicted, fluctuate, oscillate, hem and haw, dilly-dally, shilly-
shally 
Antonyms:- decide 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹  (verb intransitive) vacillate (between) ঝিিা্করা; ঝিিাঝন্বি্হওযা; দদাদুলঝচ্ত্ত/বদালাযমা /বদালাঝযি/বদাদুল্হওযা;

 ❑ vacillation [ভযাঝসবলইশন্]্্(noun) [countable noun, uncountable noun] দদাদুলযমা িা; দদালাচ্লঝচ্ত্তিা।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Ask her for an opinion, and she'll give it to you without any hesitation or attempts to vacillate . 
 ❑ They view him as a vacillator whose tactical shifts in the face of foreign pressure have been unpardonable. 
 ❑ Ask her for an opinion, and she'll give it to you without any hesitation or attempts to vacillate . 
 ❑ My listening tastes vacillate between music and talk radio. 
 ❑ The government should give leadership, and not procrastinate and vacillate , he said, although he recognised it 
could take 20 years. 
 ❑ I had for a time vacillated between teaching and journalism 
 ❑ My children bring me great joy (especially as the little ones vacillate between squirming with curiosity and 
tittering with barely kept secrets in anticipation of Christmas).

 ❑ he said, although he recognised it could take 20 years.

 ❑ Don’t confuse this word with venial (VEE nee ul), which means trivial or pardon able. A peccadillo is a 
venial, harmless sin.  
Synonyms:- bribable, corrupt, corruptible, dishonest, purchasable 
Antonyms:- incorruptible

🎯 VERACITY ➺  ( vuh RAS uh tee ) [ দভযমাঝসঝট]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  সিযোঝদিা, সিযঝ ষ্ঠ, সিয, সিযপরাযণিা, অ‍ঝেিথ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  n truthfulness  
 ❑ The veracity of young George Washington is apocryphal. 
 ❑ Veracious (vuh RAY shus) means truthful.  
Synonyms:- sincerity, sooth 
Antonyms:- deceit, deceitfulness, lying, mendacity 
Examples:- 
 ❑ Is this a genuine reference, or are there doubts about its veracity ? 
 ❑ After the improbability of all that recently transpired, he couldn't see fit to doubt Aarrl's veracity . 
 ❑ Did they not realise the extent of Archer's problems with veracity ? 
 ❑ officials expressed doubts concerning the veracity of the story 
 ❑ If anyone doubted the veracity of his research or the authenticity of his photographs, he would fly into a violent 
rage. 
 ❑ Unfortunately, the marketability of spy stories is determined by their drama, not by their veracity . 
 ❑ I suggest that the minister test my veracity on this to see whether I am telling the truth. 
 ❑ Cooke gilded that story for days, insisting on its veracity and refusing to tell the police where the boy lived. 
 ❑ Because of my developing view that there is often more verisimilitude than veracity in folk wisdom, I carried out 
a replication.

🎯 VERISIMILITUDE ➺  ( ver uh si MIL uh tood ) [ দভঝরঝসঝমঝলঝটযঊড, দভঝরঝসঝমঝলটূড]   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  আপাি্সিয, সিযেৎ্প্রিীযমা ্েস্তু, সিয্েঝলযা্প্রিীযমা িা   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  n similarity to reality; the appear ance of truth; looking like the real thing  
 ❑ They used pine cones and old truck tires to make statues of Hol ly wood celebrities that were 
remarkable for their veri si mil i tude.  
 ❑ The verisimilitude of counterfeit eleven-dollar bills did not fool the eagle-eyed treasury officer, who 
recognized them im me di ate ly for what they were.  
Synonyms:- camouflage, color of law, colour of law, disguise, face value, guise, pretence, pretense, pretext, 
simulacrum 
Antonyms:- falseness 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

দকাব াঝকছু; আপািসিয।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Poe saw how •all are affected by the potent magic of verisimilitude . 
 ❑ Jonson's use of strict verisimilitude helps to facilitate yet another layer of deception by employing a fixed sense of 
time.

fiction's past.

 ❑ That is, does it have verisimilitude 
 ❑ the appearance of being true or real?

                              http://  



📚 Ultimate Job Solutions 🔎UJS 
 ❑ The unhappy young man found vestiges of his fiancée in the rubble, but the explosion had effectively 
ended their romance. 
 ❑ An old uniform and a tattered scrapbook were the only ves tig es of the old man’s career as a 
professional athlete. 
 ❑ Your appendix is a vestige: It used to have a function, but now this organ does nothing. 
 ❑ The adjective form of vestige is vestigial (vuh STIJ ee ul). The appen dix is referred to as a vestigial 
organ. It is still in our bodies, al though it no longer has a function. It is a mere vestige of some function 
our digestive systems no longer perform. 
 ❑ Note carefully the pronunciation of both parts of speech.  
Synonyms:- remnant, fragment, relic, echo, indication, sign, trace, residue, mark, legacy, reminder,

🎯 VICARIOUS ➺  ( vye KAR ee us ) [ ঝভবকআঝরআস্, ভাইবকআঝরআস্, ঝভকযাঝরযাস্]্

Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj experienced, performed, or suf fered through some one else; living through 
the ex pe ri enc es of an oth er as though they were one’s own experiences  
 ❑ To take vicarious pleasure in someone else’s success is to enjoy that person’s success as though it

 ❑ We all felt a vicarious thrill when the mayor’s daughter won fourth prize in the regional kickboxing 
competition.  
Synonyms:- indirect, secondhand, secondary, derivative, derived, surrogate, substitute, empathetic,

Antonyms:- bland 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

ruler.

majority who watch these movies to get a vicarious experience of falling in love.

and will save all men.

doyen, veteran, star, champion, hotshot, wizard, magician, pro

ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  গন্ধকজ, গন্ধকপূণম, গন্ধকঝমঝেি, গন্ধকিুলয, ঝেধ্বিংসী, গাবয জ্বালা-িরাব া, হল-বফাটাব া, দখ্াাঁচ্া-বদওযা

Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj quick to evaporate; highly unstable; explo sive  
 ❑ A volatile liquid is one that evaporates readily. Gasoline is a vol a tile liquid. It evaporates readily, 
and then the vapor poses a great danger of explosion. 
 ❑ A volatile crowd is one that seems to be in imminent danger of getting out of control or exploding. 
 ❑ The situation in the Middle East was highly volatile; the smallest in ci dent could have set off a war. 
 ❑ To be volatile is to be characterized by volatility.  
Synonyms:- unpredictable, changeable, variable, inconstant, inconsistent, erratic, irregular, unstable,

whimsical, fickle, flighty, impulsive, temperamental, high-strung, excitable, emotional, fiery, moody, 
tempestuous 
Antonyms:- certain, constant, immutable, invariable, settled, stable, stationary, steady, unchangeable, 
unchanging, nonvolatile 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-

 ❑ volatility [ভলাঝটলাঝট]্(noun) উিাঝযিা; চ্লঝচ্ত্তিা; প্রাবণাচ্ছলিা; প্রাণচ্াঞ্চলয।  
Examples:- 
 ❑ Reports already indicated that sales figures were very volatile , even when the growth was still brisk.

suspended in a volatile substance such as acetone.

growth of plants as far as 27 feet away.

 ❑ But it has made international affairs a volatile and unpredictable realm.

 ❑ Born in 1626 in Smyrna, Turkey, he was by all accounts a brilliant, charismatic if emotionally volatile man. 
 ❑ As ordinary life becomes more volatile 
 ❑ insecure and unpredictable in various ways, people search for security in whatever ways they can muster. 
 ❑ The only evidence for this is circumstantial: there was no civil war and he was in power at a volatile time.

অ‍সচ্চঝরত্র েযঝি, দখ্যাঝলভাবে্চ্লা, রঙ্গ্করা, ঝিঝড়িং্-্ঝিঝড়িং্ াচ্া   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj malicious; unjustifiable; unp rov oked; egreg ious  
 ❑ Terrorists commit wanton acts on a helpless populace to make their point. 
 ❑ Wanton also means intemperate. 
 ❑ A hedonist lives a wanton life in the relentless, unremitting pursuit of pleasure; an ascetic does not.  
Synonyms:- bend over backwards, commit, dawdle, fling, fritter away, frivol, loosen up, lose it, make as if, 
menace, misspend, move, nickel-and-dime, optimize, relax, sentimentalize, splurge, squander, tope, use 
up, bisexual, bisexual person, bon vivant, cocksucker, epicure, epicurean, erotic, foodie, gastronome, 
gourmet, hedonist, light-o'-love, light-of-love, pagan, pleasure seeker, sybarite, voluptuary, easy, light, 
loose, motiveless, promiscuous, sluttish, unchaste, unmotivated, unprovoked 
Antonyms:- clean, decent, wholesome, justifiablerestrainedchaste 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 ১্(সাঝহঝিযক)্দকৌিুকঝপ্রয; দাঝযত্বজ্ঞা হী ; দখ্যাঝল:্a wanton breeze, দখ্যাঝল্োিাস; পাগলা্হাওযা; in a wanton 
mood, দখ্যাঝল দমজাবজ। 
 ❑ ২্অ‍োি; উচৃ্ছঙ্খল; িা্িা্কবর্োড়বছ্এম ; েুব া:্a wanton growth of weeds. 
 ❑ ৩্দস্বচ্ছাচ্ারী; উবেশযহী :্wanton destruction.

 ❑ ৪্(পুরাি ী)্ ীঝিঝেগঝহমি; অ‍সিী:্a wanton woman; wanton thoughts.

 ❑ wantonly

Examples:-

 ❑ Their wanton vandalism causes money to be wasted and toilets to close.

🎯 WILLFUL ➺  ( WIL ful )   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  ঝ রঙু্কশ, দস্বচ্ছাচ্ারী, দস্বচ্ছাকৃি, দস্বচ্ছাচ্াঝলি, জ্ঞা কৃি, একগুাঁবয, ইচ্ছাকৃি   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj deliberate; obstinate; insistent on hav ing one’s way  
 ❑ The mother insisted that the killing committed by her son had not been willful, but the jury 
apparently believed that he had known what he was doing. 
 ❑ When her mother told her she couldn’t have a cookie, the willful little girl simply snatched the cookie 
jar and ran out of the room with it. She had stolen the cookies willfully.  
 ❑ Note carefully the spelling of this word.  
Synonyms:- disobedient, froward, headstrong, self-willed, voluntary, wilful 
Examples:- 
 ❑ Several were notorious for their willful neglect of logistic matters. 
 ❑ This willful act was in direct violation of Article 5 of the United Nations Convention on children. 
 ❑ Stubborn, willful , bold and determined, natives born into this combination all take themselves and their actions 
very seriously. 
 ❑ willful acts of damage 
 ❑ We control universal processes, as a willful act of mankind, through these discoveries. 
 ❑ Even when others act where you have not done so, you continue with your willful neglect in the face of crisis and 
misery. 
 ❑ Stubborn, willful 
 ❑ bold and determined, natives born into this combination all take themselves and their actions very seriously. 
 ❑ They can also be willful 
 ❑ arrogant and stubborn. 

 

🎯 WISTFUL ➺  ( WIST ful ) [ উইস্ট্্ফ্ল,্ উইস্টা্ফু্ল]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  সিৃষ্ণ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj yearning; sadly longing  
 ❑ I felt wistful when I saw Steve’s fancy new car. I wished that I had enough money to buy one for 
myself. 
 ❑ The boys who had been cut from the football team watched wist ful ly as the team put together an 
undefeated season and won the state cham pi on ship.

Synonyms:- pensive, sad 
Antonyms:- satisfied 
Detailed Bangla Meaning:-  
 🗹 ঝেষণ্ণ্ও্েযাকুল;  ামহী ্অ‍িৃি্োস ায্িাঝড়ি: wistful eyes; a wistful look. 
 ❑ wistfully [উইস্ট্্ফ্াঝল]্(adverb) ঝেষণ্ণ্ও্েযাকুলভাবে; অ‍িৃি্োস ায্িাঝড়ি্হবয:্look wistfully at something.  
Examples:- 
 ❑ They ran through emotions from funny, romantic and sad, to witty, wistful and thought-provoking. 
 ❑ The entire point of this post wasn't to engage in wistful remembrances. 
 ❑ She chuckled lightly and exhaled a sigh caught somewhere in between wistful and dreamy. 
 ❑ a wistful smile 
 ❑ Director Bob Baker seems to have an innate understanding of the Coward paradox, that wistful vitriol. 
 ❑ It has a wistful quality, a longing for a world gone never to return, which an author of Sampson's vintage can 
and should be excused. 
 ❑ Tin became wistful and in a surge of nostalgia offered to show me round. 
 ❑ What distinguishes Harcourt from his contemporaries is the way he laces his stories with wistful charm and 
surreal humour. 
 ❑ He held in a wistful sigh and smiled warmly when her eyes flicked up in the mirror, meeting his. 

 

🎯 ZEALOUS ➺  ( ZEL us ) [ দজলাস্]্   
ব া াংল া  অ র্ থঃ  অ‍িযন্ত্আগ্র্হশীল, প্রেল্উেীপ াপূণম, আগ্র্হপূণম, গভীর অ‍ ুভূঝিপূণম, প্রেল্আগ্র্হপূণম, প্রেল্উিসাহপূণম, আগ্র্হদীি, 
আগ্র্হাঝম্বি, িৎপর, সাগ্র্বহ্ঝ রি, একান্ত্অ‍ ুরি, একান্তভাবে্সমথম কর, একান্ত্আসি, িমমান্ধিাপূণম, দসাৎসাহী, দসাৎসাহ   
Word Smart Meaning:➭  adj enthusiastically devoted to some thing; fervent  
 ❑ The zealous young policeman made so many arrests that the city jail soon became overcrowded. 
 ❑ The dictator’s followers were so zealous that if he had asked them all to jump off a cliff, most of them 
would have done so. 
 ❑ To be zealous is to be full of zeal, or fervent enthusiasm. An overly zealous person is a zealot. ☞☞  
Synonyms:- fervent, ardent, fervid, fanatical, passionate, impassioned, devout, devoted, 
committed, dedicated, hard-core, enthusiastic, eager, keen, overkeen, avid, card-carrying, 
vigorous, energetic, intense, fierce, perfervid 
Antonyms:- apathetic 
Examples:- 
 ❑ Now in their 50s, she and her husband are zealous promoters of the mission they began in 1981. 
 ❑ Pastor Boichenko is indeed a zealous Pastor and evangelist always leading from the front. 
 ❑ Just how zealous is the religious right? 
 ❑ They are also extremists of one kind or another who have devoted themselves to the zealous pursuit of their 
religious ideals. 
 ❑ Throughout a pulsating and fiercely-contested match, Kendal were unable to please the zealous match official. 
 ❑ the council was extremely zealous in the application of the regulations 
 ❑ Ann Lee and her immediate entourage were unbowed in their zealous commitment. 
 ❑ Pastor Boichenko is indeed a zealous Pastor and evangelist always leading from the front. 
 ❑ Will we see these zealous litter police staking out public houses. 
 ❑ Such zealous passion would seem to be the natural preserve of that dangerous species, the young man.
